sourceDesc.bibl: Transcribed from: Comedies and tragedies / written by Francis Beaumont and Iohn Fletcher, Gentlemen .... -- London : Printed for Humphrey Robinson, at the three Pidgeons, and for Humphrey Moseley at the Princes Armes in St Pauls church-Yard, 1647. -- First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. -- "The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.

div.head: Actus Primus. Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Bonduca, daughters, Hengo, Nennius, souldiers.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: the hardy Romanes? O ye gods of Britain,
the rust of arms, the blushing shame of souldiers;
are these the men that conquer by inheritance?
The fortune-makers? These the julians, Enter Caratach
that with the sun measure the end of nature,
making the world but one Rome and one Caesar?
Shame, how they flee Caesars soft soul dwells in 'em;
their mothers got 'em sleeping, pleasure nurst 'em,
their bodies sweat with sweet oils, loves allurements,
not lustie arms. Dare they send these to seek us,
these Romane girls? Is Britain grown so wanton?
Twice we have beat'em, Nennius, scatter'd 'em,
and through their big-bon'd germans, on whose pikes
the honour of their actions sit in triumph,
made themes for songs to shame 'em, and a woman,
a woman beat 'em, Nennius; a weak woman,
a woman beat these Romanes.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: so it seems.
A man would shame to talk so.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: who's that?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: i.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: cousin, do you grieve my fortunes?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: no, Bonduca,
if I grieve, 'tis the bearing of your fortunes;
you put too much winde to your sail: discretion
and hardie valour art the twins of honour,
and nurs'd together, make a conquerour:
divided, but a talker. 'T is a truth,
that Rome has fled before us twice, and routed;
a truth we ought to crown the gods for, lady,
and not our tongues. A truth is none of ours,
nor in our ends, more then the noble bearing:
for then it leaves to be a vertue, lady;
and we that have been victors, beat our selves,
when we insult upon our honours subject.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: my valiant cousin, is it foul to say
what liberty and honour bid us do,
and what the gods allow us?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: no, Bonduca,
so what we say, exceed not what we do.
Ye call the Romanes fearful, fleeing Romanes,
and Romane girls, the lees of tainted pleasures:
does this become a doer? Are they such?

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: they are no more.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: where is your conquest then?
Why are your altars crown'd with wreathes of flowers,
the beasts with gilt horns waiting for the fire?
The holy druides composing songs
of everlasting life to victory?
Why are these triumphs, lady? For a may-game?
For hunting a poor herd of wretched Romanes?
Is it no more? Shut up your temples, Britains.
And let the husband-man redeem his heifers;
put out our holy fires; no timbrel ring;
let's home, and sleep; for such great overthrows,
a candle burns too bright a sacrifice,
a glow-worms tail too full a flame. O Nennius,
thou hadst a noble uncle knew a Romane,
and how to speak him, how to give him weight
in both his fortunes.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: by---I think
ye doat upon these Romanes, Caratach.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: witnesse these wounds, I do; they were fairly given.
I love an enemy:I was born a souldier;
and he that in the head on's troop defies me,
bending my manly body with his sword,
I make a mistris. Yellow-tressed hymen
ne'er ty'd a longing virgin with more joy,
then I am married to that man that wounds me:
and are not all these Romane? Ten struck battels
I suckt these honour'd scars from, and all Romane:
ten yeers of bitter nights and heavie marches,
when many a frozen storm sung thorow my curasse,
and made it doubtful whether that or i
were the more stubborn metal, have I wrought thorow,
and all to try these Romanes. Ten times a night
I have swom the rivers, when the stars of Rome
shot at me as I floated, and the billows
tumbled their watry ruines on my shoulders,
charging my batter'd sides with troops of agues;
and still to try these Romanes, whom I found
(and if I lye, my wounds be henceforth backward,
and be you witnesse, gods, and all my dangers)
as ready, and as full of that I brought
(which was not fear nor flight) as valiant,
as vigilant, as wise, to do and suffer,
ever advanced as forward as the Britains,
their sleeps as short, their hopes as high as ours,
i, and as subtil, lady. 'Tis dishonour,
and, follow'd, will be impudence, Bonduca,
and grow to no belief, to taint these Romanes.
Have not I seen the Britains-

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: what?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: dishearted,
run, run, Bonduca, not the quick rack swifter:
the virgin from the hated ravisher
not half so fearful? Not a flight drawn home,
a round stone from a sling, a lovers wish
ere made that haste that they have. By-
I have seen these Britains, that you magnifie,
run as they would have out-run time, and roaring
basely for mercy, roaring: the light shadows:
that in a thought scur ore the fields of corn,
halted on crutches to 'em.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: o ye powers,
what scandals do I suffer?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: yes, Bonduca,
I have seen: thee run too, and thee, Nennius;
yea, run apace, both; then when Penyus
the Romane girl cut thorow your armed carts,
and drive 'em headlong on ye down the hill;
then when he hunted ye, like Britain-foxes,
more by the sent then sight: then did I see
these valiant and approved men of Britain,
like boading owls, creep into tods of ivie,
and hoot their fears to one another nightly.

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: and what did you then, Caratach?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: I fled too,
but not so fast; your jewel had been lost then,
young Hengo there; he trasht me, Nennius:
for when your fears out-run him, then stept i,
and in the head of all the Romane fury
took him, and with my tough belt to my back
I buckled him; behinde him, my sure sheild;
and then I follow'd. If I say I fought
five times in bringing off this bud of Britain,
I lye not, Nennius. Neither had ye heard
me speake this, or ever seen the childe more,
but that the son of vertue, Penyus,
seeing me steer thorow all these storms of danger,
my helm still in my hand, my sword my prow,
turn'd to my fo my face, he cri'd out nobly,
go, Britain, bear thy lions whelp off safely;
thy manly sword has ransom'd thee:grow strong,
and let me meet thee once again in arms;
then if thou stand'st, thou art mine. I took his offer,
and here I am to honour him.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: o cousin,
from what a flight of honour hast thou checkt me?
What wouldst thou make me, Caratach?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: see, lady,
the noble use of others in our losses;
does this afflict ye? Had the Romanes cri'd this,
and as we have done theirs, sung out these fortunes,
rail'd on our base condition, hooted at us,
made marks as far as the earth was ours, to shew us,
nothing but sea could stop our flights; despis'd us;
and held it equal whether banquetting
or beating of the Britains were more businesse,
it would have gall'd ye.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: let me think we conquer'd.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: do; but so think, as we may be conquer'd:
and where we have found vertue, though in those
that came to make us slaves, let's cherish it.
There's not a blowe we gave since julius landed,
that was of strength and worth, but like records
they file to after-ages. Our registers,
the Romanes, are for noble deeds of honour;
and shall we burn their mentions with upbraidings?

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: no more, I see my self:thou hast made me, cousin,
more then my fortunes durst; for they abus'd me,
and wound me up so high, I swell'd with glory:
thy temperance has cur'd that tympany,
and given me health again, nay, more discretion.
Shall we have peace?for now I love these Romanes.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: thy love and hate are both unwise ones, lady.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: your reason?

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: is not peace the end of arms?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: not where the cause implies a general conquest:
had we a difference with some pettie isle,
or with our neighbours (lady)for our land marks,
the taking in of some rebellious lord,
or making a head against commotions,
after a day of blood, peace might be argued:
but where we grapple for the ground we live on,
the libertie we hold as dear as life,
the gods we worship, and next those, our honours,
and with those swords that know no end of battel:
those men beside themselves allow no neighbour;
those mindes that where the day is claim inheritance,
and where the sun makes ripe the fruits, their harvest,
and where they march, but measure out more ground
to adde to Rome, and here i'th'bowels on us;
it must not be; no, as they are our foes,
and those that must be so until we tire'em,
let's use the peace of honour, that's fair dealing,
but in our ends, our swords. That hardy Romane
that hopes to graft himself into my stock,
must first begin his kinred under ground,
and be alli'd in ashes.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: Caratach,
as thou hast nobly spoken, shall be done;
and Hengo to thy charge I here deliver:
the Romanes shall have worthy wars.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: they shall.
And, little sir, when your young bones grow stiffer,
and when I see ye able in a morning
to beat a dozen boys, and then to breakfast,
I'll tye ye to a sword.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: and what then, uncle?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: then ye must kill, sir, the next valiant Romane
that calls ye knave.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: and must I kill but one?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: an hundred, boy, I hope.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: I hope five hundred.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: that's a noble boy. Come, worthy lady,
let's to our several charges, and henceforth
allow an enemy both weight and worth. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Secunda
div.stage: Enter Junius and Petillius, two Romane captains.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: what ailst thou, man? Dost thou want meat?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: no.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: clothes?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: neither. For heavens love, leave me.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: drink?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: ye tire me.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: come, 't is drink; I know't is drink.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: 'tis no drink.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I say 't is drink:for what affliction
can light so heavie on a souldier,
to dry him up as thou art, but no drink?
Thou shalt have drink.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: prethee, Petillius-

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: and by mine honour, much drink, valiant drink:
never tell me, thou shalt have drink. I see,
like a true friend, into thy wants: 'tis drink;
and when I leave thee to a desolation,
especially of that dry nature, hang me.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: why do you do this to me?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: for I see,
although your modestie would fain conceal it,
which sits as sweetly on a souldier,
as an old side-saddle.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: what do you see?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I see as far as day, that thou want'st drink.
Did I not finde thee gaping like an oyster
for a new tide? Thy very thoughts lie bare
like a lowe ebbe? Thy soul that rid in sack,
lies moor'd for want of liquor? Do but see
into thy self; for by-I do:
for all thy body's chapt, and crackt like timber
for want of moisture:what thou wantst there, Junius,
and if it be not drink.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: you have too much on't.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: it may be a whore too; say it be:come, meecher,
thou shalt have both:a pretty valiant fellow,
die for a little lap and lechery?
No, it shall ne'er be said in our countrey,
thou dy'dst o'th'chin-cough. Heare, thou noble Romane,
the son of her that loves a souldier,
hear what I promised for thee; thus I said,
lady, I take thy son to my companion,
lady, I love thy son, thy son loves war,
the war loves danger, danger drink, drink discipline,
which is society and lechery;
these two beget commanders:fear not, lady,
thy son shall lead.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: 'tis a strange thing, Petillius,
that so ridiculous and loose a mirth
can master your affections.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: any mirth,
and any way, of any subject, Junius,
is better then unmanly mustinesse:
what harm's in drink, in a good wholesom wench?
I do beseech ye, sir, what errour? Yet
it cannot out of my head handsomly,
but thou wouldst fain be drunk: come, no more fooling;
the general has new wine, new come over.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: he must have new acquaintance for it too,
for I will none, I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: none, I thank ye?
A short and touchie answer. None I thank ye:
ye do not scorn it, do ye?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: gods defend sir;
I owe him still more honour.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: none, I thank ye:
no company, no drink, no wench, I thank ye.
Ye shall be worse intreated, sir.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: Petillius,
as thou art honest, leave me.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: none, I thank ye;
a modest and a decent resolution,
and well put on. Yes, I will leave ye, Junius,
and leave ye to the boys, that very shortly
shall all salute ye, by your new sirname
of Junius none I thanke ye. I would starve now,
hang, drown, despaire, deserve the forks, lie open
to all the dangerous passes of a wench,
bound to believe her tears, and wed her aches,
ere I would own thy follies. I have found ye
your lays, and out-leaps Junius, haunts, and lodges:
I have view'd ye, and I have found ye by my skill
to be a fool o'th'first head, Junius,
and I will hunt ye: ye are in love, I know it:
ye are an asse, and all the camp shall know
a peevish idle boy:your dame shall know it:
a wronger of my care; your self shall know it.Enter corporal Judas, and four souldiers.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: a bean? A princely diet, a full banquet,
to what we compasse.

sp.speaker: 1 sould
sp.l: fight like hogs for acorns?

sp.speaker: 2 sould
sp.l: venture our lives for pig-nuts?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: what ail these rascals?

sp.speaker: 3 sould
sp.l: if this hold, we are starv'd.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: for my part, friends,
which is but twenty beans a day, a hard world
for officers, and men of action;
and those so clipt by master mouse, and rotten:
for understand 'em french beans, where the fruits
are ripen'd like the people, in old tubs.
For mine own part, I say, I am starv'd already,
not worth another bean, consum'd to nothing,
nothing but flesh and bones left, miserable:
now if this mustie provender can prick me
to honourable matters of atchievement, gentlemen,
why there's the point.

sp.speaker: 4 sould
sp.l: I'll fight no more.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: you'll hang then,
a soveraign help for hunger. Ye eating rascals,
whose gods are beef and brewis, whose brave angers
do execution upon these, and chibbals:
ye dogs heads i'th'porridge pot; you fight no more?
Does Rome depend upon your resolution
for eating mouldy pie-crust?

sp.speaker: 3 sould
sp.l: would we had it.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: I may do service, captain.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: in a fish-market.
You, corporal curry-comb, what will your fighting
profit the common-wealth?do you hope to triumph,
or dare your vamping valour, good man cobler,
clap a new foal to th'kingdom? S'death, ye dog-whelps
you, fight, or not fight.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: captain.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: out, ye flesh-flyes,
nothing but noyce and nastinesse.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: give us meat,
whereby we may do.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: whereby hangs your valor?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: good bits afford good blows.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: a good position:
how long is't since thou eat'st last? Wipe thy mouth,
and then tell truth.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: I have not eat to th'purpose-

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: to th' purpose? What's that? Half a cow, and garlick?
Ye rogues, my company eat turf, and talk not;
timber they can digest, and fight upon't;
old matts, and mud with spoons, rare meats. Your shoes, slaves,
dare ye cry out of hunger, and those extant?
Suck your sword-hilts, ye slaves, if ye be valiant;
honour will make 'em march-pain:to the purpose?
A grievous penance. Dost thou see that gentleman,
that melancholy monsieur?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: pray ye, Petillius.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: he has not eat these three weeks.

sp.speaker: 2 sould
sp.l: 'has drunk the more then.

sp.speaker: 3 sould
sp.l: and that's all one.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: nor drunk nor slept these two months.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: captain, we do beseech you as poor souldiers,
men that have seen good days, whose mortal stomacks,
may somtime feel afflictions.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: this, Petillius,
is not so nobly done.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: 'tis common profit;
urge him to th'point, he'll finde you out a food
that needs no teeth nor stomack; a strange formity
will feed ye up as fat as hens i'th'foreheads,
and make ye fight like fichocks, to him.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: captain.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: do you long to have your throats cut?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: see what metal
it makes in him:two meals more of this melancholy,
and there lies Caratach.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: we do beseech ye.

sp.speaker: 2 sould
sp.l: humbly beseech your valour.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: am I onely
become your sport, Petillius?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: but to render
in way of general good, in preservation.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: out of my thoughts, ye slaves.

sp.speaker: 4 sould
sp.l: or rather pitie.

sp.speaker: 3 sould
sp.l: your warlike remedy against the maw-worms.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: or notable receipt to live by nothing.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: out with your table-books.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: is this true friendship?
And must my killing griefs make others may-games?
Stand from my swords point, slaves; your poor starv'd spirits
can make me no oblations; else, o love,
thou proudly blind destruction, I would send thee
whole hecatombs of hearts, to bleed my sorrows.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: alas, he lives by love, sir, exit Junius.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: so he does, sir,
and cannot you do so too? All my company
are now in love, ne'er think of meat, nor talk
of what provant is:aymees, and hearty hey-hoes,
are sallets fit for souldiers. Live by meat,
by larding up your bodies? 'T is lewd, and lazie,
and shews ye meerly mortal, dull, and drives ye
to fight like camels, with baskets at your noses.
Get ye in love; ye can whore well enough,
that all the world knows: fast ye into famine,
yet ye can crawl like crabs to wenches, handsomly.
Fall but in love now, as ye see example,
and follow it but with all your thoughts, probatum,
there's so much charge sav'd, and your hungers ended.
Away, I hear the general: get ye in love all, drum afar off
up to the ears in love, that I may hear
no more of these rude murmurings; and discreetly
carry your stomacks, or I prophesie
a pickel'd rope will choke ye. Jog, and talk not.
sp.stage: Enter Swetonius, Demetrius, Decius, drum, colours.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: Demetrius, is the messenger dispatch'd
to Penyus, to command him to bring up
the volans regiment?

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: he's there by this time.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: and are the horse well view'd we brought from mona?

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: the troops are full, and lusty.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: good Petillius,
looke to those eating rogues, that bawl for victuals,
and stop their throats a day or two:provision
waits but the winde to reach us.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: sir, already
I have been tampring with their stomacks, which I finde
as deaf as adders to delays:your clemency
hath made their murmurs, mutinies, nay, rebellions:
now, and they want but mustard, they're in uproars:
no oil but candy, lucitanian figs,
and wine from lestos, now can satisfie 'em:
the british waters are grown dull and muddy,
the fruit disgustful:orontes must be fought for,
and apples from the happie isles:the truth is,
they are more curious now in having nothing,
then if the sea and land turn'd up their treasures:
this lost the colonies, and gave Bonduca
(with shame we must record it) time and strength
to looke into our fortunes; great discretion
to follow offered victory; and last, full pride
to brave us to our teeth, and scorn our ruines.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: nay, chide not, good Petillius, I confesse
my will to conquer mona, and long stay
to execute that will, let in these losses:
all shall be right again, and as a pine
rent from oeta by a sweeping tempest,
joynted again, and made a mast, defies
those angry windes that split him:so will i,
piec'd to my never-failing strength and fortune,
steer thorow these swelling dangers, plow their prides up,
and bear like thunder through their loudest tempests:
they keep the field still.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: confident and full.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: in such a number, one would swear they grew,
the hills are wooded with their partizans,
and all the valleys over-grown with darts,
as moors are with rank rushes:no ground left us
to charge upon, no room to strike:say fortune
and our endeavours bring us in to 'em,
they are so infinite, so ever-springing,
we shall be kill'd with killing; of desperate women,
that neither fear, or shame ere found, the devill
has rankt amongst 'em multitudes:say the men fail,
they'll poison us with their petticoats:say they fail,
they have priests enough to pray us into nothing,

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: these are imaginations, dreams of nothings,
the man that doubts or fears.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: I am free of both.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: the self-same i.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: and I as free as any;
as carelesse of my flesh, of that we call life,
so I may lose it nobly; as indifferent
as if it were my diet. Yet, noble general,
it was a wisedom learn'd from you; I learn'd it,
and worthy of a souldiers care, most worthy,
to weigh with most deliberate circumstance
the ends of accidents, above their offers;
how to go on and get, to save a Romane,
whose one life is more worth in way of doing,
then millions of these painted wasps; how viewing
to finde advantage out; how, found, to follow it
with counsel and discretion, lest meer fortune
should claim the victory.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: 'tis true, Petillius,
and worthily remembred:the rule's certain,
their uses no lesse excellent:but where time
cuts off occasions, danger, time and all
tend to a present peril, 'tis required
our swords and manhoods be best counsellors,
our expeditions, presidents. To win, is nothing,
where reason, time and counsel are our camp-masters:
but there to bear the field, then to be conquerours,
where pale destruction takes us, takes us beaten,
in wants, and mutinies, our selves but handfuls,
and to our selves our own fears, needs a new way,
a sudden and a desperate execution:
here, how to save, is losse; to be wise, dangerous;
onely a present well-united strength,
and mindes made up for all attempts, dispatch it:
disputing and delay here, cools the courage;
necessity gives time for doubts; things infinite,
according to the spirit they are preach'd to,
rewards like them; and names for after-ages,
must steel the souldier; his own shame help to arm him;
and having forc'd his spirit, ere he cools,
fling him upon his enemies; sudden and swift,
like tygers amongst foxes, we must fight for't:
fury must be our fortune; shame we have lost,
spurs ever in our sides to prick us forward:
there is no other wisedom nor discretion
due to this day of ruine, but destruction;
the souldiers order first, and then his anger.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: no doubt they dare redeem all.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: then no doubt
the day must needs be ours. That the proud woman
is infinite in number, better likes me,
then if we dealt with squadrons:half her army
shall choke themselves, their own swords dig their graves.
I'll tell ye all my fears, one single valour,
the vertues of the valiant Caratach
more doubts me then all Britain:he's a souldier
so forg'd out, and so temper'd for great fortunes,
so much man thrust into him, so old in dangers,
so fortunate in all attempts, that his meer name
fights in a thousand men, himself in millions,
to make him Romane. But no more. Petillius,
how stands your charge?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: ready for all employments,
to be commanded too, sir.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: 't is well govern'd;
to morrow we'll draw out, and view the cohorts:
i'th'mean time, all apply their offices.
Where's Junius?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: in's cabbin.
Sick o'th'mumps, sir.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: how?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: in love, indeed in love, most lamentably loving,
to the tune of queen dido,

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: alas poor gentleman.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: 't will make him fight the nobler. With what lady?
I'll be a spokesman for him.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: you'll scant speed, sir.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: who is't?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: the devils dam, Bonduca's daughter,
her youngest, crackt i'th'ring.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: I am sorry for him:
but sure his own discretion will reclaim him,
he must deserve our anger else. Good captains,
apply your selves in all the pleasing forms
ye can, unto the souldiers; fire their spirits,
and set 'em fit to run this action;
mine owne provision shall be shar'd amongst 'em.
Till more come in: tell 'em, if now they conquer,
the fat of all the kingdom lies before 'em,
their shames forgot, their honours infinite,
and want for ever banisht. Two days hence,
our fortunes, and our swords, and gods be for us. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: I must come?

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: so the general commands, sir.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: I must bring up my regiment?

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: believe, sir,
I bring no lye.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: but did he say, I must come?

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: so delivered.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: how long is't, Regulus, since I commanded
in Britain here?

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: about five yeers, great Penyus.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: the general some five months. Are all my actions
so poor, and lost, my services so barren,
that i'm remembred in no nobler language
but must come up?

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: I do beseech ye, sir,
weigh but the times estate.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: yes, good lievtenant,
I do, and his that sways it. Must come up?
Am I turn'd bare centurion?must, and shall,
fit embasses to court my honour?

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: sir-

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: set me to lead a handful of my men
against an hundred thousand barbarous slaves
that have marcht name by name with Romes best doers?
Serve 'em up some other meat; I'll bring no food
to stop the jaws of all those hungry wolfs.
My regiment's mine own. I must, my language.Enter Curius.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: Penyus, where lies the host?

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: where fate may finde 'em.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: are they ingirt?

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: the battel's lost.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: so soon?

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: no; but 't is lost, because it must be won:
the Britains must be victors. Who ere saw
a troop of bloody vultures hovering
about a few corrupted carcases,
let him behold the silly Romane host,
girded with millions of fierce Britain swains,
with deaths as many as they have had hopes;
and then go thither, he that loves his shame;
I scorn my life, yet dare not lose my name.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: do not you hold I a most famous end,
when both our names and lives are sacrific'd
for Romes encrease?

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: yes, Curius; but mark this too;
what glory is there, or what lasting fame
can be to Rome, or us? What full example,
when one is smother'd with a multitude,
and crowded in amongst a namelesse presse?
Honour got out of flint, and on their heads
whose vertues, like the sun, exhal'd all valours,
must not be left in mists and fogs of people,
notelesse, and out of name, but rude and naked:
nor can Rome task us with impossibilities,
or bid us fight against a flood:we serve her,
that she may proudly say she has good souldiers,
nor slaves to choke all hazards. Who but fools,
that make no difference betwixt certain dying,
and dying well, would fling their fames and fortunes
into this Britain-gulf, this quicksand-ruine,
that sinking, swallows us? What noble hand
can finde a subject fit for blood there? Or what sword
room for his execution? What air to cool us,
but poison'd with their blasting breaths and curses,
where we lie buried quick above the ground,
and are with labouring sweat, and breathlesse pain,
kill'd like to slaves, and cannot kill again?

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: Penyus, mark ancient wars, and know that then
captains weigh'd an hundred thousand men.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: Drusius, mark ancient wisdom, and you'll finde then
he gave the overthrow that sav'd his men.
I must not go.

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: the souldiers are desirous,
their eagles all drawn out, sir.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: who drew up Regulus?
Ha? Speak: did you?whose bold will durst attempt this?
Drawn out? Why, who commands, sir?on whose warrant
durst they advance?

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: I keep mine own obedience.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: 't is like the general cause, their love of honour,
relieving of their wants.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: without my knowledge?
Am I no more? My place but at their pleasures?
Come, who did this?

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: by-sir, I am ignorant. drum softly within: then enter souldiers with drum and colours.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: what, am I grown a shadow?heark, they march.
I will know, and will be my self. Stand, disobedience:
he that advances one foot higher, dies for't.
Run thorow the regiment upon your duties,
and charge 'em on command:beat back again,
by-I'll tith'em all else.

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: we'll do our best.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: back; cease your bawling drums there,
I'll beat the tubs about your brains else. Back:
do I speak with lesse fear then thunder to ye?
Must I stand to beseech ye? Home, home:ha?
Do ye stare upon me?are those mindes I moulded,
those honest valiant tempers I was proud
to be a fellow to, those great discretions
made your names fear'd and honour'd, turn'd to wildfires?
O gods, to disobedience? Command, farewel;
and be ye witnesse with me, all things sacred,
I have no share in these mens shames. March, souldiers
and seek your own sad ruines; your old Penyus
dares not behold your murders.

sp.speaker: sould
sp.l: captain.

sp.speaker: 2 sould
sp.l: captain.

sp.speaker: 3 sould
sp.l: dear honour'd captain.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: too too dear lov'd souldiers,
which made ye weary of me:and heaven yet knows,
though in your mutinies, I dare not hate you;
take your own wills; 't is fit your long experience
should now know how to rule your selves:I wrong ye,
in wishing ye to save your lives and credits,
to keep your necks whole from the ax hangs ore ye:
alas, I much dishonour'd ye: go, seek the Britains,
and say ye come to glut their sacrifices;
but do not say I sent ye. What ye have been,
how excellent in all parts, good, and govern'd,
is onely left of my command, for story;
what now ye are, for pitie. Fare ye well.Enter Drusius and Regulus.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: oh turn again, great Penyus; see the souldier
in all points apt for duty.

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: see his sorrow
for his disobedience, which he says was haste,
and haste (he thought) to please you with. See, captain,
the toughnesse of his courage turn'd to water;
see how his manly heart melts.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: go, beat homeward,
there learn to eat your little with obedience,
and henceforth strive to do as I direct ye.

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: my answer, sir.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: tell the great general,
my companies are no fagots to fill breaches;
my selfe no man that must, or shall, can carry:
bid him be wise; and where he is, he's safe then;
and when he findes out possibilities,
he may command me. Commend me to the captains.

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: all this I shall deliver.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: farewel, Macer. Exit Penyus.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: pray gods this breed no mischief.

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: it must needs,
if stout Swetonius win; for then his anger,
besides the souldiers losse of due, and honour,
will break together on him.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: he's a brave fellow;
and but a little hide his haughtinesse,
(which is but sometimes neither, on some causes)
he shews the worthiest Romane this day living.
You may, good Curius, to the general
make all things seem the best.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: I shall endeavour:
pray for our fortunes, gentlemen. If we fall,
this one farewel serves for a funeral.
The gods make sharp our swords, and steel our hearts;
we dare, alas, but cannot fight our parts.

div.head: Scaena Secunda
div.stage: Enter Junius, Petillius and a herald.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: let him go on:stay, now he talks.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: why?
Why should I love mine enemie? What is beauty?
Of what strange violence, that like the plague,
it works upon our spirits? Blind they faign him,
I am sure, I find it so.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: a dog shall lead ye.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: his fond affections blinder.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: hold ye there still.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: it takes away my sleep,

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: alas, poor chicken.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: my company, content; almost my fashion.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: yes, and your weight too, if you follow it.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: 'tis sure the plague, for no man dare come neer me
without an antidote:'tis far worse; hell.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: thou art damn'd without redemption then.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: the way to't
strew'd with fair western smiles, and april blushes,
led by the brightest constellations; eyes,
and sweet proportions, envying heaven:but from thence
no way to guide, no path, no wisdome brings us.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: yes, a smart water, Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: do I fool?
Know all this, and fool still? Do I know further,
that when we have enjoy'd our ends, we lose 'em,
and all our appetites are but as dreams
wee laugh at in our ages.

sp.speaker: petil
sp.l: sweet philosopher

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: do I know on still and yet know nothing? Mercie gods,
why am I thus ridiculous?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: motley on thee,
thou art an arrant asse.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: can red and white,
an eye, a nose, a cheek,

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: but one cheek, Junius?
An half-fac'd mistris?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: with a little trim,
that wanton fools call fashion, thus abuse mee?
Take me beyond my reason?why should not i
doat on my horse well trapt, my sword well hatch'd?
They are as handsom things, to mee more usefull,
and possible to rule too. Did I but love,
yet 'twere excusable, my youth would bear it;
but to love there, and that no time can give me,
mine honour dare not ask: shee has been ravish'd
my nature, must not know; she hates our nation.
Thus to dispose my spirit

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: stay a little,
he will declame again.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: I will not love; I am a man, have reason,
and I will use it:I'll no more tormenting,
nor whining for a wench, there are a thousand,

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: hold thee there boy.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: a thousand will intreat me.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: ten thousand, Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: I am young and lustie,
and to my fashion valiant; can please nightly.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I'll swear thy back's probatum, for I have known thee
leap at sixteen like a strong stallion.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: I will be man again.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: now mark the working,
the divell and the spirit tug for't: twenty pound
upon the divels head.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: I must be wretched.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I knew I had won.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: nor have I so much power
to shun my fortune.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I will hunt thy fortune
with all the shapes imagination breeds, musick
but I will fright thy divell:stay, he sings now. song, by Junius, and Petillius after him in mockage.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: must I be thus abus'd?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: yes mary must ye.
Let's follow him close: oh, there he is, now read it.

sp.speaker: herald
sp.l: reads it is the generals command, that all sick,
persons old and unable, retire within the trenches; hee that
fears his libertie, to leave the field: fools, boyes, and lovers
must not come neer the regiments, for fear of their infections;
especially those cowards they call lovers.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: hah?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: read on.

sp.speaker: herald
sp.l: if any common souldier love an enemie, hee's
whip'd and made a slave: if any captain; cast, with losse
of honours, flung out o'th' army, and made unable ever after
to beare the name of a souldier.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: the-----consume ye all, rogues. exit Jun.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: let this work:
h'as something now to chew upon:he's gone,
come, shake no more.

sp.speaker: her
sp.l: well, sir, you may command me,
but not to doe the like again for europe:
I would have given my life for a bent two-pence.
If I ere read to lovers whilst I live again,
or come within their confines-

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: there's your payment,
and keep this private.

sp.speaker: her
sp.l: I am school'd for talking. Exit Herald. Enter Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: how now, Demetrius, are we drawn?

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: 'tis doing:
your company stands fair; but pray ye, where's Junius?
Half his command are wanting, with some forty
that Decius leads.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: hunting for victuals:
upon my life free-booting rogues, their stomacks
are like a widows lust, nere satisfied.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: I wonder how they dare stir, knowing the enemy
master of all the countrey.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: resolute hungers
know neither fears, nor faiths, they tread on ladders,
ropes, gallowes, and overdoe all dangers.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: they may be hang'd though.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: there's their joyfull supper,
and no doubt they are at it.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: but for heavens sake,
how does young Junius?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: drawing on, poor gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: what, to his end?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: to th'end of all flesh:woman.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: this love has made him a stout souldier.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: o, a great one,
fit to command young goslings:but what news?

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: I think the messenger's come back from Penyus
by this time, let's go know.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: what will you say now
if he deny to come, and take exceptions
at some half syllable, or found deliverd
with an ill accent, or some stile left out?

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: I cannot think he dare.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: he dare speak treason,
dare say, what no man dares beleeve, dares doe-
but that's all one:I'll lay you my black armour
to twenty crowns, he comes not.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: done.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: you'll pay.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: then keep thine old use Penyus,
be stubborn and vain glorious, and I thank thee.
Come let's go pray for six hours: most of us
I fear, will trouble heaven no more:two good blowes
struck home at two commanders of the Britains,
and my part's done.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: I do not think of dying.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: 'tis possible we may live. But Demetrius,
with what strange legs, and arms, and eyes, and noses,
let carpenters and copper-smiths consider.
If I can keep my heart whole, and my wind-pipe,
that I may drink yet like a souldier-

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: come, let's have better thoughts; mine's on
your armour.

sp.speaker: petil
sp.l: mine's in your purse, sir:let's go try the wager.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Judas and his four companions (halters about their necks) Bonduca, her daughters, Nennius following.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: come, hang'm presently.

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: what made your rogueships
harrying for victuals here? Are we your friends?
Or doe you come for spies? Tell me directly,
would you not willingly be hang'd now? Do not ye long for't?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: what say ye? Shall wee hang in this vain? Hang we must,
and 'tis as good to dispatch it merrily,
as pull an arse like dogs to't.

sp.speaker: 1. Soul
sp.l: any way,
so it be handsome.

sp.speaker: 3. Soul
sp.l: I had as lief 'twere toothsom too:but all agree,
and I'll not out boyes.

sp.speaker: 4. Soul
sp.l: let's hang plesantly.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: then plesantly be it: captain, the truth is,
we had as lief hang with meat in our mouthes,
as ask your pardon empty.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: these are brave hungers.
What say you to a leg of beef now, sirha?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: bring me acquainted with it, and I'll tell ye.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: torment 'em wenches:I must back; then hang 'em.

sp.speaker: jud.
sp.l: we humbly thank your grace.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh
sp.l: the rogues laugh at us.

sp.speaker: 2.daugh
sp.l: sirha, what think you of a wench now?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: a wench, lady?
I do beseech your ladiship, retire,
I'll tell ye presently, ye see the time's short;
one crash; even to the setling of my conscience.

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: why, is't no more but up, boyes?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: yes, ride too captain.
Will you but see my feat?

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh
sp.l: ye shall be set, sir,
upon a jade shall shake ye.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: sheets, good madam,
will do it ten times better.

sp.speaker: 1 daugh
sp.l: whips, good souldier,
which ye shall taste before ye hang, to mortifie ye;
'tis pitie ye should die thus desperate.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh
sp.l: these are the merry Romans, the brave mad-caps.
'Tis ten to one wee'll cool your resolutions.
Bring out the whips.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: would your good ladyships
would exercise 'em too.

sp.speaker: 4. Soul
sp.l: surely ladies,
we'ld shew you a strange patience.

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: hang 'em rascals,
they'l talk thus on the wheel. Enter Caratach.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: now what's the matter?
What are these fellows? Whats the crime committed,
that they wear necklaces?

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: they are Roman rogues,
taken a forraging.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: is that all, Nennius?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: would I were fairly hang'd; this is the divell,
the kill-cow Caratach.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: and you would hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: are they not enemies?

sp.speaker: 1. Soul
sp.l: my breech makes buttons.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh
sp.l: are they not our tormentors?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: tormentors? Flea-traps.
Pluck off your halters, fellows.

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: take heed, Caratach,
taint not your wisdome.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: wisdome, Nennius?
Why, who shall fight against us, make our honours,
and give a glorious day into our hands,
if we dispatch our foes thus? What's their offence?
Stealing a loafe or two to keep out hunger,
a piece of greazie bacon, or a pudding?
Do these deserve the gallows? They are hungry,
poor hungry knaves, no meat at home left, starv'd:
art thou not hungry?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: monstrous hungry.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: he looks like hungers self:get 'em some victuals,
and wine to cheer their hearts, quick: hang up poor pilchers?

sp.speaker: 2. Soul
sp.l: this is the bravest captain-

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: Caratach,
I'll leave you to your will.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: I'll answer all, sir.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh
sp.l: let's up, and view his entertainment of 'em.
I am glad they are shifted any way, their tongues else
would still have murdred us.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh
sp.l: let's up, and see it. Exeunt. Enter Hengo.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: sit down poor knaves:why, where's this wine
and victuals?
Who waites there?

sp.speaker: suit
sp.l: sir, 'tis coming.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: who are these uncle?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: thy are Romans, boy.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: are these they
that vex mine aunt so? Can these fight? They look
like emptie scabbards, all, no mettle in 'em,
like men of clouts, set to keep crows from orchards;
why, I dare fight with these.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: that's my good chicken. And how do ye?
How do you feel your stomacks?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: wondrous apt, sir,
as shall appear when time calls.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: that's wel, down with't,
a little grace will serve your turns:eat softly,
you'll choak ye knaves else: give 'em wine.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: not yet, sir,
we're even a little busie.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: can that fellow
do any thing but eat? Thou fellow.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: away boy,
away, this is no boyes play.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: by---, uncle,
is his valour lie in's teeth, he's the most valiant.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: I am glad to hear ye talk, sir.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: good uncle tell me,
what's the price of a couple of cramm'd Romans?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: some twenty Britains boy; these are good soldiers,

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: do not the cowards eat hard too?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: no more, boy.
Come, I'll sit with you too; sit down by me, boy.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: pray bring your dish then.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: hearty knaves:more meat there.

sp.speaker: 1. Soul
sp.l: that's a good hearing.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: stay now and pledge me.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: this little piece sir.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: by-----square eaters,
more meat I say; upon my conscience
the poor rogues have not eat this month:how terribly
they charge upon their victuals:dare ye fight thus?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: beleeve it sir, like devils,

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: wel said famine,
here's to thy general.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: most excellent captain, I wil now pledge thee.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: and to morrow night, say to him,
his head is mine.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: I can assure ye captain,
he wil not give it for this washing.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: wel said. daughters above.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh
sp.l: here's a strange entertainment: how the
theeves drink.

sp.speaker: 2. Daug
sp.l: danger is dry, they look'd for colder liquor.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: fil 'em more wine, give 'em ful bowls; which of
you all now
in recompence of this good, dare but give me
a sound knock in the battell?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: delicate captain,
to doe thee a sufficient recompence,
I'll knock thy brains out.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: do it.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: thou dar'st as well be damn'd: thou knock his
brains out.
Thou skin of man? Uncle, I will not hear this.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: tie up your whelp.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: thou kill my uncle?
Would I had but a sword for thy sake, thou dry'd dog.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: what a mettle
this little vermine caries.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: kill mine uncle?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: he shall not, child.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: he cannot:he's a rogue,
an onely eating rogue: kill my sweet uncle?
Oh that I were a man.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: by this wine,
which I will drink to captain Junius,
who loves the queens most excellent majesties little daughter
most sweetly, and most fearfully, I will do it.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: uncle, I'll kill him with a great pin.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: no more, boy.
I'll pledge thy captain:to ye all, good fellows.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh
sp.l: in love with me? That love shall cost your
lives all:
come sister, and advise me; I have here
a way to make an easie conquest of 'em,
if fortune favour me.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: let's see ye sweat
to morrow, blood and spirit, boyes, this wine
turn'd to sterne valour.

sp.speaker: 1. Soul
sp.l: heark ye Judas,
if he should hang us after all this.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: let him:
I'll hang like a gentleman, and a Roman.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: take away there,
they have enough.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: captain, wee thank you heartily
for your good cheer, and if we meet to morrow,
one of us payes for't.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: get 'em guides, their wine Enter 2d daughter and a servant
has over master'd 'em.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh
sp.l: that hungry fellow
with the red beard there, give it him, and this,
to see it well deliverd.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: farewell, knaves;
speak nobly of us, keep your words to morrow, Enter a guide
and doe something worthy your meat. Go, guide 'em,
and see 'em fairly onward.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: meaning me, sir?

sp.speaker: serv
sp.l: the same.
The youngest daughter to the queen intreats ye
to give this privately to captain Junius,
this for your pains.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: I rest her humble servant.
Commend me to thy lady. Keep your files, boyes.

sp.speaker: serv
sp.l: I must instruct ye farther.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: keep your files there.
Order, sweet friends: faces about now.

sp.speaker: guide
sp.l: here sir,
here lies your way.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: 'blesse the founders, I say.
Fairly, good souldiers, fairly march now: close, boyes.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Swetonius, Petillius, Demetrius, Decius, Macer.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: bid me be wise, and keep me where I am,
and so be safe: not come, because commanded;
was it not thus?

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: it was, sir.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: what now think ye?

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: must come, so hainous to him, so distastefull?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: give me my money.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: I confesse 'tis due sir,
and presently I'll pay it.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: his obedience
so blind at his yeers and experience,
it cannot find where to be tendred?

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: sir,
the regiment was willing, and advanc'd too,
the captains at all points steel'd up; their preparations
full of resolve, and confidence; youth and fire,
like the fair breaking of a glorious day,
guilded their falanx:when the angrie Penyus
stept like a stormy cloud 'twixt them and hopes.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: and stopt their resolutions?

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: true: his reason
to them was ods, and ods so infinite,
discretion durst not look upon.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: well Penyus,
I cannot think thee coward yet; and treacherous
I dare not think:thou hast lopt a limb off from me,
and let it be thy glory, thou wast stubborn,
thy wisdome, that thou leftst thy generall naked:
yet ere the sun set, I shall make thee see,
all valour dwels not in thee; all command
in one experience. Thou wilt too late repent this,
and wish, I must come up, had been thy blessing.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: let's force him.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: no, by no means; he's a torrent
we cannot easily stemme.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I think, a traitor.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: no il words:let his own shame first revile him.
That wine I have, see it (Demetrius)
distributed amongst the souldiers,
to make 'em high and lustie: when that's done,
Petillius, give the word through, that the eagles
may presently advance:no man discover,
upon his life, the enemies full strength,
but make it of no value:Decius,
are your starv'd people yet come home?

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: keep 'em in more obedience:this is no time
to chide, I could be angry else, and say more to ye:
but come, let's order all: whose sword is sharpest,
and valour equall to his sword this day,
shall by my saint.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: we shall be holy all then. Exeunt. Enter Judas and his company.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: captain, captain, I have brought 'em off again;
the drunkenest slaves.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: ---confound your rogueships;
I'll call the generall, and have ye hang'd all.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: pray who will you command then?

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: for you, sirha,
that are the ring-leader to these devises,
whose maw is never cramm'd, I'll have an engine.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: a wench, sweet captain.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: sweet Judas, even the forks.
Where ye shall have two lictors with two whips
hammer your hide.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: captain, good words, fair words,
sweet words, good captain; if you like not us,
farewell, we have imployment.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: where hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: there where you dare not be with all your valour.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: where's that?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: with the best good-fellow living.

sp.speaker: 1. Soul
sp.l: the king of all good-fellows.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: who's that?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: Caratach.
Shake now, and say , wee have done something worthie,
mark me; with Caratach: by this---Caratach:
do you asmuch now and you dare: sweet Caratach.
Ye talk of a good fellow, of true drinking;
wel, go thy waies, old Caratach:besides the drink captain,
the bravest running banquet of black puddings,
peeces of glorious beef.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: how scapt ye hanging?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: hanging's a dogs death: we are gentlemen,
and I say still, old Caratach.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: belike then,
you are turn'd rebels all.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: we are Roman boyes all,
and boyes of mettle:I must doe that captain,
this day, this very day.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: away, ye rascal.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: fair words, I say again.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: what must you doe, sir?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: I must do that my heart-strings yern to do:
but my word's past.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: what is it?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: why, kill Caratach.
That's all he ask'd us for our entertainment.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: more then you'll pay.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: would I had sold my self
unto the skie, I had not promis'd it:
for such another Caratach.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: come fool,
have ye done your country service?

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: I have brought that
to captain iunius.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: how?

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: I think will doe all:
I cannot tell, I think so.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: how? To iunius?
I'le more enquire of this:you'll fight now?

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: promise:
take heed of promise, captain.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: away, and rank then.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: but heark ye captain, there is wine distributing,
I would fain know what share I have.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: be gone.
Ye have too much.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: captain, no wine, no fighting.
There's one call'd Caratach, that has wine.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: well sir,
if you'll be rul'd now, and doe well.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: doe excellent.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: ye shall have wine, or any thing; goe file;
I'll see ye have your share:drag out your dormise,
and stow 'em somwhere, where they may sleep handsomly,
they'l hear a hunt's up shortly.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: now I love thee:
but no more forks nor whips.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: deserve 'em not then:
up with your men, I'll meet ye presently;
and get 'em sober quickly.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: arm, arm, bullyes;
all's right again and straight; and which is more,
more wine, more wine: awake ye men of memphis,
be sober and discreet, we have much to do boyes. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: mess
sp.l: prepare there for the sacrifice, the queen comes. musick enter in solemnity, the druids singing, the second daughter strewing flowers: then Bonduca, Caratach, Nennius, and others.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: ye powerfull gods of Britain, hear our prayers;
hear us you great revengers, and this day
take pitie from our swords, doubt from our valours,
double the sad remembrance of our wrongs
in every brest; the vengeance due to those
make infinite and endlesse:on our pikes
this day pale terror sit, horrors and ruines
upon our executions; claps of thunder
hang on our armed carts, and 'fore our troops
despair and death; shame beyond these attend 'em.
Rise from the dust, ye relicks of the dead,
whose noble deeds our holy druids sing,
oh rise, ye valiant bones, let not base earth
oppresse your honours, whilest the pride of Rome
treads on your stocks, and wipes out all your stories.

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: thou great tiranes, whom our sacred priests,
armed with dreadfull thunder, place on high
above the rest of the immortall gods,
send thy consuming fires and deadly bolts,
and shoot 'em home; stick in each Roman heart
a fear fit for confusion; blast their spirits,
dwell in 'em to destruction; thorow their phalanx
strike, as thou strik'st a proud tree; shake their bodies,
make their strengths totter, and their toplesse fortunes
unroot, and reel to ruine.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh
sp.l: o thou god,
thou feared god, if ever to thy justice
insulting wrongs, and ravishments of women,
women deriv'd from thee, their shames, the suffrings
of those that daily fill'd thy sacrifice
with virgin incense, have accesse, now hear me,
now snatch thy thunder up, now on these Romans,
despisers of thy power, of us defacers,
revenge thy self; take to thy killing anger,
to make thy great work full, thy justice spoken,
an utter rooting from this blessed isle
of what Rome is or has been.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: give more incense,
the gods are deafe and drowsie; no happy flame
rises to raise our thoughts: pour on.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh
sp.l: see heaven,
and all you pow'rs that guide us, see, and shame
we kneel so long for pitie over your altars;
since 'tis no light oblation that you look for,
no incense offring, will I hang mine eyes;
and as I wear these stones with hourly weeping,
so will I melt your pow'rs into compassion.
This tear for prosutagus my brave father,
ye gods, now think on Rome; this for my mother,
and all her miseries; yet see, and save us:
but now ye must be open ey'd. See, heaven,
o see thy showrs stoln from thee; our dishonours, a smoak from the altar
o sister, our dishonours: can ye be gods,
and these sins smother'd?

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: the fire takes.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: it does so,
but no flame rises, cease your fearfull prayers,
your whinings, and your tame petitions;
the gods love courage arm'd with confidence,
and prayers fit to pull them down:weak tears
and troubled hearts, the dull twins of cold spirits,
they sit and smile at. Hear how I salute 'em:
divine audate, thou who hold'st the reins
of furious battels, and disordred war,
and proudly roll'st thy swarty chariot wheels
over the heaps of wounds, and carcasses,
sailing through seas of bloud; thou sure-steel'd sternnesse,
giue us this day good hearts, good enemies,
good blowes o'both sides, wounds that fear or flight
can claim no share in; steel us both with angers,
and warlike executions fit thy viewing;
let Rome put on her best strength, and thy Britain,
thy little Britain, but as great in fortune,
meet her as strong as shee, as proud, as daring;
and then look on, thou red ey'd god: who does best,
reward with honour; who despair makes flie,
unarme for ever, and brand with infamie:
grant this, divine audate, 't is but justice;
and my first blow thus on thy holy altar a flame arises
I sacrifise unto thee.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: it flames out. musick.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: now sing ye druides. song.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: 'tis out again.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: h'as given us leave to fight yet; we ask no more,
the rest hangs in our resolutions:
tempt him no more.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: I would know further cosen,

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: his hidden meaning dwels in our endeavours;
our valours are our best gods. Cheer the souldier,
and let him eat.

sp.speaker: mess
sp.l: he's at it, sir.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: away then;
when he has done, let's march. Come, fear not lady,
this day the Roman gains no more ground here,
but what his body lies in.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: now I am confident. Exeunt recorders.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: we dare not hazzard it:beside our lives,
it forfeits all our understandings.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: gentlemen,
can ye forsake me in so just a service,
a service for the common-wealth, for honour?
Read but the letter; you may love too.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: read it:
if there be any safety in the circumstance,
or likelihood 'tis love we will not faile ye.
Read it good Curius.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: willingly.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: now mark it.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: health to thy heart, my honourd Junius,
and all thy love requited:I am thine,
thine everlastingly, thy love has won me,
and let it breed no doubt; our new acquaintance
compels this, 'tis the gods decree to blesse us.
The times are dangerous to meet; yet fail not,
by all the love thou bear'st me I conjure thee,
without distrust of danger, to come to me,
for I have purpos'd a delivery
both of my self and fortune this blest day
into thy hands, if thou thinkst good:to shew thee
how infinite my love is, even my mother
shall be thy prisoner, the day yours without hazzard;
for I beheld your danger like a lover,
a just affecter of thy faith: thy goodnesse,
I know, will use us nobly, and our marriage,
if not redeem, yet lessen Romes ambition.
I am weary of these miseries: use my mother,
(if you intend to take her) with all honour,
and let this disobedience to my parents
be laid on love, not me. Bring with thee, Junius,
spirits resolv'd to fetch me off, the noblest,
forty will serve the turn; just at the joyning
of both the battels, we will be weakly guarded;
and for a guide, within this hour shall reach thee
a faithfull friend of mine:the gods, my Junius,
keep thee, and me to serve thee:young bonvica.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: this letter carries much belief, and most objections
answer'd, we must have doubted.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: is that fellow
come to ye for a guide yet?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: yes.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: and examin'd?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: far more then that; he has felt tortures, yet
he vows he knows no more then this truth.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: strange.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: if she mean what she writes, as't may be probable,
'twill be the happiest vantage we can lean to.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: I'll pawn my soul she means truth.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: think an hour more,
then if your confidence grow stronger on ye,
we'll set in with ye

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: nobly done; I thank ye;
ye know the time.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: we will be either ready
to give ye present counsell, or joyne with ye. Enter Swetonius, Petillius, and Demetrius, Macer.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: no more as ye are gentlemen. The generall.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: draw out a pace, the enemy waits for us;
are ye all ready?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: all our troops attend, sir.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: I am glad to hear you say so, Junius.
I hope ye are dispossest.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: I hope so too, sir.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: continue so. And gentlemen, to you now;
to bid you fight is needlesse, ye are Romans,
the name will fight it self; to tell ye who
you go to fight against, his power, and nature,
but losse of time:ye know it, know it poor,
and oft have made it so. To tell ye further,
his bodie showes more dreadfull then it has done,
to him that fears, lesse possible to deal with,
is but to stick more honour on your actions,
load ye with vertuous names, and to your memories
tie never dying time, and fortune constant.
Go on in full assurance, draw your swords
as daring and as confident as justice;
the gods of Rome fight for ye; loud fame calls ye,
pitch'd on the toplesse perinine, and blows
to all the under world:all nations,
the seas, and unfrequented deserts, where the snow dwels,
wakens the ruin'd monuments, and there
where nothing but eternall death and sleep is,
informs again the dead bones. With your vertues,
go on, I say, valiant and wise, rule heaven,
and all the great aspects attend 'em. Do but blow
upon this enemy, who, but that we want foes,
cannot deserve that name; and like a myst,
a lazie fog, before your burning valours
you'll finde him flie to nothing. This is all,
we have swords, and are the sons of ancient Romans,
heirs to their endlesse valours, fight and conquer.

sp.speaker: de. Dem
sp.l: 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: that man that loves not this day,
and hugs not in his arms the noble danger,
may he die famelesse and forgot.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: sufficient,
up to your troops, and let your drums beat thunder,
march close, and sudden like a tempest:all executions march
done without sparkling of the body:keep your phalanx
sure lin'd, and piec'd together; your pikes forward,
and so march like a moving fort: ere this day run,
we shal have ground to add to Rome, wel won. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: the Roman is advanc'd from yound'hils brow,
we may behold him, Caratach. a march drums within at one place afar off.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: let's thither,
I see the dust flie. Now I see the body,
observe 'em , Nennius; by-----a handsome body,
and of a few, strongly and wisely joynted:
Swetonius is a souldier.

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: as I take it,
that's hee that gallops by the regiments,
viewing their preparations.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: very likely,
he shews no lesse then generall:see how bravely
the body moves, and in the head how proudly
the captains stick like plumes:hee comes apace on;
good Nennius go, and bid my stout leutenant
bring on the first square bodie to oppose 'em,
and as he charges, open to enclose 'em:
the queen move next with hers, and wheel about,
to gain their backs, in which I'll lead the vantguard.
We shall have bloody crowns this day, I see by't;
haste thee good Nennius, I'll follow instantly. exit Nennius
how close they march, as if they grew together? march
no place but lin'd alike: sure from oppression;
they will not change this figure: we must charge 'em,
and charge 'em home at both ends, van and rere, drums in another place afar off
they never totter else. I hear our musick,
and must attend it:hold good sword, but this day,
and bite hard where I hound thee, and hereafter
I'll make a relique of thee, for young souldiers
to come like pilgrimes to, and kisse for conquests. exit

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: now is the time, the fellow stayes.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: what think yee?

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: I think 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: alas, if 'twere a question,
if any doubt or hazzard fell into't,
do ye think mine own discretion so self-blinde,
my care of you so naked, to run headlong?

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: let's take Petillius with us.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: by no means:
hee's never wise but to himself, nor courteous,
but where the end's his own:we are strong enough,
if not too many. Behind yonder hill
the fellow tels me she attends, weak guarded,
her mother and her sister.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: I would venture.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: wee shall not strike five blows for't: weigh the good,
the generall good may come.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: away, I'll with ye,
but with what doubt?

sp.speaker: fun
sp.l: fear not, my soul for all. Exeunt. Alarms, drums and trumpets in severall places afar off, as at a main battel.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: here ye may see 'em all, sir; from this hill
the country shews off levell.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: gods defend me,
what multitudes they are, what infinites?
The Roman power shews like a little star
hedg'd with a double halloa. Now the knell rings, loud shouts
heark how they shout to th'battell; how the air
totters and reels, and rends apieces, Drusus,
with the huge vollied clamours.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: now they charge.
Oh gods, of all sides, fearfully.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: little Rome,
stand but this growing hydra one short hour,
and thou hast out-done hercules.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: the dust hides 'em,
we cannot see what follows.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: they are gone,
gone, swallow'd, Drusus; this eternall sun
shall never see 'em march more.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: o turn this way,
and see a modell of the field, some forty,
against four hundred.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: well fought, bravely follow'd;
o nobly charg'd again, charg'd home too: Drusus,
they seem to carry it:now they charge all, loud
close, close, I say; they follow it: ye gods,
can there be more in men? More daring spirits?
Stil they make good their fortunes. Now they are gone too,
for ever gone: see Drusus, at their backs
a fearfull ambush rises. Farewell valours,
excellent valours: o Rome, where's thy wisdome?

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: they are gone indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: look out toward the army,
I am heavie with these slaughters.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: 'tis the same still,
cover'd with dust and fury. Enter the two daughters, with Junius, Curius, Decius, and souldiers.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh
sp.l: bring 'em in,
tie 'em, and then unarm 'em.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh
sp.l: valiant Romans,
ye are welcome to your loves,

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh
sp.l: your death, fools.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: we deserve 'em,
and women do your worst.

sp.speaker: 1. Daug
sp.l: ye need not beg it.

sp.speaker: 2. Daug
sp.l: which is kinde Junius?

sp.speaker: serv
sp.l: this.

sp.speaker: 2. Dau
sp.l: are you my sweet heart?
It looks ill on't:how long is't, pretty soul,
since you and I first lov'd? Had we not reason
to doat extreamly upon one another?
How does my love? This is not he: my chicken
could prate finely, sing a love-song.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: monster.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh
sp.l: oh, now it courts.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: arm'd with more malice
then he that got thee has the divell.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh
sp.l: good.
Proceed, sweet chick.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: I hate thee, that's my last.

sp.speaker: 2. Daug
sp.l: nay, and ye love me, forward: no? Come sister,
let's prick our answers on our arrows points,
and make 'em laugh a little. Ye damn'd leachers,
ye proud improvident fools, have we now caught ye?
Are ye i'th'noose? Since ye are such loving creatures,
wee'll be your cupids: do ye see these arrows?
Wee'll send 'em to your wanton livers, goats.

sp.speaker: 1. Dau
sp.l: o how I'll trample on your hearts, ye villains,
ambitious salt-itcht slaves:Romes master sins,
the mountain rams topt your hot mothers.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh
sp.l: dogs,
to whose brave founders a salt whore gave suck;
theeves, honours hangmen, do ye grin? Perdition
take me for ever, if in my fell anger, Enter Caratach
I doe not out-doe all example.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: where,
where are these ladies? Ye keep noble quarter,
your mother thinks ye dead or taken; upon which,
she will not move her battell. Sure these faces
I have beheld and known, they are Roman leaders,
how came they here?

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh
sp.l: a trick sir, that we us'd,
a certain policie conducted 'em
unto our snare: we have done ye no small service;
these us'd as we intend, we are for th'battell.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: as you intend? Taken by treachery?

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh
sp.l: is't not allow'd?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: those that should gild our conquest,
make up a battell worthie of our winning,
catch'd up by craft?

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh
sp.l: by any means that's lawfull.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: a womans wisedome in our triumphs? Out,
out ye sluts, ye follies; from our swords
filch our revenges basely? Arm again, gentlemen:
souldiers, I charge ye help 'em.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh
sp.l: by-----uncle,
we will have vengeance for our rapes.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: you should have kept your legs close then: dispatch there.

sp.speaker: 1 daugh
sp.l: I will not off thus.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: he that stirs to execute,
or she, though it be your selves, by him that got me,
shall quickly feel mine anger:one great day given us,
not to be snatch'd out of our hands but basely;
and must we shame the gods from whence we have it,
with setting snares for souldiers? I'll run away first,
be hooted at, and children call me coward
before I set up scales for victories:
give 'em their swords.

sp.speaker: 2. Daug
sp.l: o gods.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: bear off the women
unto their mother.

sp.speaker: 2. Dau
sp.l: one shot, gentle uncle.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: one cut her fiddle-string:bear 'em off I say.

sp.speaker: 1. Dau
sp.l: the----take this fortune.

sp.speaker: cara
sp.l: learn to spin,
and curse your knotted hemp:goe gentlemen,
Exeunt.daughters. safely go off, up to your troops:be wiser,
there thank me like tall souldiers: I shall seek ye. exit Caratach.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: a noble worth.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: well Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: pray ye no more.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: he blushes, do not load him.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: where's your love now? drums loud again.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: puffe, there it flies: come, let's redeem our follies.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: awake, sir; yet the Roman bodie's whole,
I see'em cleer again.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: whole? 'Tis not possible:
Drusus, they must be lost.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: by-----they are whole, sir,
and in brave doing; see, they wheel about
to gain more ground.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: but see there Drusus, see,
see that huge battell moving from the mountains,
their gilt coats shine like dragons scales, their march
like a rough tumbling storm; see them, and view 'em.
And then see Rome no more: say they faile; look,
look where the armed carts stand; a new army:
look how they hang like falling rocks, as murdring
death rides in triumph Drusus:fell destruction
lashes his fiery horse, and round about him
his many thousand wayes to let out soules.
Move me again when they charge, when the mountain
melts under their hot wheels, and from their ax'trees
huge claps of thunder plough the ground before 'em,
till then I'll dream what Rome was.Enter Swetonius, Petillius, Demetrius, Macer.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: o bravely fought; honour till now nere show'd
her golden face i'th'field. Like lions, gentlemen,
y'have held your heads up this day: where's yong Junius,
Curius, and Decius?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: gone to heaven, I think, sir.

sp.speaker: sw
sp.l: their worths go with'em:breath a while: how do ye?

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: wel, some few scurvie wounds, my heart's whole yet.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: would they would give us more ground.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: give? Wee'll have it.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: have it? And hold it too, despight the divell.Enter Junius, Decius, Curius.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: lead up th th'head, and line sure:the qs.battell
begins to charge like wild-fire:where's the generall?

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: oh, they are living yet. Come, my brave souldiers,
come, let me powr Romes blessing on ye; live,
live, and lead armies all:ye bleed hard.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: best:
wee shall appear the sterner to the foe.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: more wounds, more honour.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: lose no time.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: away then,
and stand this shock, ye have stood the world.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: wee'll grow to't.
Is not this better now then lowsie loving?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: I am my self, Petillius.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: 'tis I love thee. Exeunt.Romans. Enter Bonduca, Caratach, daughters, Nennius.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: charge 'em i'th'flanks:o ye have plaid the fool,
the fool extremely, the mad fool.

sp.speaker: Bon
sp.l: why cosin?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: the woman fool. Why did you give the word
unto the carts to charge down, and our people
in grosse before the enemie?we pay for't,
our own swords cut out throats:why? ---on't,
why do you offer to command? The divell,
the divell, and his dam too, who bid you
meddle in mens affairs? Exeunt.queen, and c.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: I'll help all.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: home,
home and spin woman, spin, go spin, ye trifle.
Open before there, or all's ruine. How, showts within
now comes the tempest; on our selves, by--- Victoria within
o woman, scurvie woman, beastly woman. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: Victoria, Victoria.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: how's that, Drusus?

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: they win, they win, they win; oh look, look, look, sir,
for heavens sake look, the Britains fly, the Britains fly.
Victoria. Enter Swetonius, souldiers, and captains.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: soft, soft, pursue if soft; excellent souldiers,
close, my brave fellows, honourable Romans:
oh cool thy mettle Junius, they are ours,
the world cannot redeem 'em: stern Petillius,
govern the conquest nobly:soft, good souldiers.Enter Bonduca, daughters, and Britains.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: shame, whither flie ye, ye unluckie Britains?
Will ye creep into your mothers wombs again? Back
cowards,
hares, fearfull hares, doves in your angers; leave me?
Leave your queen desolate? Her haplesse childrenEnter Caratach and Hengo
to Roman rape again and fury?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: flie, ye buzzards,
ye have wings enough, ye fear: get thee gone, woman, loud showt within
shame tread upon thy heels: all's lost, all's lost, heark,
heark how the Romans ring our knels. ext. Bond. and c.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: good uncle,
let me go too.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: no boy, thy fortune's mine,
I must not leave thee; get behind me; shake not, Enter Petillius, Junius, Decius
I'll breech ye, if ye do boy:come, brave Romans,
all is not lost yet.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: now I'll thank thee, Caratach. fight. Drums.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: thou art a souldier: strike home, home, have at ye.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: his blows fall like huge sledges on an anvil.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: I am weary.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: so am i.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: send more swords to me.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: let's sit and rest. sit down.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: what think ye now?

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: o Drusus,
I have lost mine honour, lost my name,
lost all that was my light: these are true Romans,
and I a Britain coward, a base coward:
guide me where nothing is but desolation,
that I may never more behold the face
of man, or mankind know me:o blind fortune,
hast thou abus'd me thus?

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: good sir, be comforted;
it was your wisdome rul'd ye; pray ye go home,
your day is yet to come, when this great fortune
shall be but soile unto it. retreat.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: fool, fool, coward. exit Penyus and Drusus Enter Swetonius, Demetrius, souldiers, drums and colours.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: draw in, draw in: wel have ye fought, and worthie
Romes noble recompence; looke to your wounds,
the ground is cold and hurtfull:the proud queen
has got a fort, and there she and her daughters
defie us once again. To morrow morning
wee'll seek her out, and make her know, our fortunes
stop at no stubborn walls:come, sons of honour,
true vertues heirs:thus hatch'd with Britain blood,
let's us march to rest, and set in gules like suns.
Beat a soft march, and each one ease his neighbours. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Quartus. Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Petillius, Junius, Decius, Demetrius singing.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: smooth was his cheek,

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: and his chin it was sleek,

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: with whoop, he has done wooing.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: Junius was this captains name,
a lad for a lasses viewing,

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: ful black his eye, andplump his thigh.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: made up for loves pursuing:

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: smooth was his check,

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: and his chin it was sleek.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: with whoop, he has done wooing.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: o my vex'd thief, art thou come home again?
Are thy brains perfect?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: sound as bels.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: thy back-worm
quiet, and cast his sting, boy?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: dead, Petillius,
dead to all folly, and now my anger only.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: why, that's wel said:hang cupid and his quiver,
a drunken brawling boy:thy honour'd saint
be thy ten shillings, Junius; there's the money,
and there's the ware; square dealing:this but sweats thee
like a nesh nag, and makes thee look pin buttock'd;
the other runs thee whining up and down
like a pig in a storm, fils thy brains full of ballads,
and shews thee like a long lent, thy brave body
turn'd to a tail of green-fish without butter.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: when thou lov'st next, love a good cup of wine,
a mistris for a king, she leaps to kisse thee,
her red and white's her own; she makes good blood,
takes none away; what shee heats sleep can help,
without a groping surgeon.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: I am counsell'd,
and henceforth, when I doat again, ---

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: take heed,
ye had almost paid for't.

sp.speaker: petil
sp.l: love no more great ladies,
thou canst not step amisse then; there's no delight in 'em;
all's in the whistling of their snatcht up silks;
they're onely made for handsome view, not handling:
their bodies of so weak and wash a temper,
a rough-pac'd bed will shake 'em all to pieces;
a tough hen puls their teeth out, tyres their souls;
