plenae rimarum sunt, they are full of rynnet,
and take the skin off where they are tasted; shun 'em,
they live in cullisses like rotten cocks
stew'd to a tendernesse, that holds no tack:
give me a thing I may crush.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: thou speak'st truly:
the warres shall be my mistris now.

sp.speaker: petil
sp.l: well chosen,
for she's a bownsing lasse, she'll kisse thee at night, boy,
and break thy pate i'th' morning.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: yesterday
I found those favours infinite.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: wench good enough,
but that she talks too loud.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: she talks to th'purpose,
which never woman did yet:shee'll hold grapling,
and he that layes on best, is her best servant:
all other loves are meer catching of dotrels,
stretching of legs out onely, and trim lazinesse.Enter swet. Curius and Macer
here comes the generall.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: I am glad I have found ye:
are those come in yet that pursu'd bold Caratach?

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: not yet sir, for I think they mean to lodge him;
take him I know they dare not, 'twill be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: then haste Petillius, haste to Penyus,
I fear the strong conceit of what disgrace
h'as pull'd upon himself, will be his ruine:
I fear his souldiers fury too; haste presently,
I would not lose him for all Britain. Give him, Petillius,

sp.speaker: petil
sp.l: that that shall choak him.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: all the noble counsell,
his fault forgiven too, his place, his honour,

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: for me, I think, as handsome.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: all the comfort;
and tell the souldier, 'twas on our command
hee drew not to the battell.

sp.speaker: petil
sp.l: I conceive sir,
and will doe that shall cure all.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: bring him with ye
before the queens fort, and his forces with him,
there you shall find us following of our conquest:
make haste.

sp.speaker: petil
sp.l: the best I may. exit.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: and noble gentlemen,
up to your companies:wee'll presently
upon the queens pursuit: there's nothing done
till she be seiz'd, without her nothing won. Exeunt. short flourish.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: how does my boy?

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: I would doe well, my heart's well;
I doe not fear.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: my good boy.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: I know, uncle,
we must all die; my little brother dy'd,
I saw him die, and he dy'd smiling: sure,
there's no great pain in't uncle. But pray tell me,
whither must we goe when we are dead?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: strange questions
why, to the blessed'st place boy:ever sweetnesse
and happinesse dwels there.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: will you come to me?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: yes, my sweet boy.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: mine aunt too, and my cosins?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: all, my good childe.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: no Romans, uncle?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: no, boy.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: I should be loth to meet them there.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: no ill men,
that live by violence, and strong oppression,
come thither:'t is for those the gods love, good men.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: why, then I care not when I go:for surely
I am perswaded they love me:I never
blasphem'd 'em, uncle, nor transgrest my parents;
I always said my prayers.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: thou shalt go, then,
indeed thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: when they please.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: that's my good boy.
Art thou not weary, Hengo?

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: weary, uncle?
I have heard you say you have march'd all day in armour.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: I have, boy.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: am not I your kinsman?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: yes.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: and am not I as fully alli'd unto you
in those brave things, as blood?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: thou art too tender.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: to go upon my legs? They were made to bear me:
I can play twenty mile a day; I see no reason
but, to preserve my countrey and my self,
I should march fourty.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: what, wouldst thou be
living to wear a mans strength?

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: why a Caratach,
a Romane-hater, a scourge sent from heaven drum
to whip these proud theeves from our kingdom. Heark,
heark, uncle, heark, I hear a drum.Enter Judas and his people to the door.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: beat softly,
softly, I say; they are here: who dare charge?

sp.speaker: 1 sould
sp.l: he
that dares be knockt o'th'head:I'll not come neer him.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: retire again, and watch then. How he stares
h'as eyes would kill a dragon:mark the boy well;
if we could take or kill him. A----on ye,
how fierce ye look? See how he broods the boy;
the divil dwells in's scabbard. Back, I say,
apace, apace, h'as found us. they retire.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: do ye hunt us?

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: uncle, good uncle see, the thin starv'd rascal,
the eating Romane, see where he thrids the thickets:
kill him, dear uncle, kill him; one good blow
to knock his brains into his breech:strike's head off,
that I may pisse in's face.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: do ye make us foxes?
Here, hold my charging-staff, and keep the place, boy.
I am at bay, and like a bull I'll bear me.
Stand, stand, ye rogues, ye squirrels. exit.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: now he pays 'em:
o that I had a mans strength.Enter iudas, and c.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: here's the boy;
mine own, I thank my fortune.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: uncle, uncle;
famine is faln upon me, uncle.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: come, sir,
yeeld willingly, your uncle's out of hearing;
I'll tickle your young tail else.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: I defie thee,
thou mock-made man of mat:charge home, sirha:
hang thee, base slave, thou shakest.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: upon my conscience
the boy will beat me:how it looks, how bravely,
how confident the worm is:a scabb'd boy
to handle me thus? Yeeld, or I cut thy head off.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: thou dar'st not cut my finger:here't is, touch it.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: the boy speaks sword and buckler. Prethee yeeld, boy:
come, here's an apple; yeeld.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: by---he fears me.
I'll give you sharper language:when, ye coward,
when come ye up?

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: if he should beat me---

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: when, sir?
I long to kill thee; come, thou canst not scape me,
I have twenty ways to charge thee; twenty deaths
attend my bloody staff.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: sure't is the devil,
a dwarf, devil in a doublet.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: I have kill'd a captain, sirha, a brave captain,
and when I have done, I have kickt him thus. Look here,
see how I charge this staff.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: most certain
this boy will cut my throat, yet.Enter two souldiers, running.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould
sp.l: flee, flee, he kills us.

sp.speaker: 2. Sould
sp.l: he comes, he comes.

sp.speaker: Iud
sp.l: the devil take the hindmost.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: run, run, ye rogues, ye precious rogues, ye rank rogues.
A comes, a comes, a comes, a comes:that's he, boys.
What a brave cry they make?Enter Caratach, with a head.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: how does my chicken?

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: 'faith, uncle, grown a souldier, a great souldier;
for by the vertue of your charging-staff,
and a strange fighting face I put upon't,
I have outbrav'd hunger.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: that's my boy, my sweet boy.
Here, here's a Romane's head for thee.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: good provision.
Before I starve, my sweet-fac'd gentleman,
I'll trie your favour.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: a right compleat souldier.
Come, chicken, let's go seek some place of strength
(the countrey's full of scouts) to rest a while in,
thou wilt not else be able to endure.
The journey to my countrey, fruits, and water,
must be your food a while, boy.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: any thing:
I can eat mosse, nay, I can live on anger,
to vex these Romanes. Let's be wary, uncle.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: I warrant thee; come chearfully.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: and boldly. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: the souldier shall not grieve ye.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: pray ye forsake me;
look not upon me, as ye love your honours;
I am so cold a coward, my infection
will choke your vertues like a damp else.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: dear captain,

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: most honour'd sir.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: most hated, most abhor'd;
say so, and then ye know me, nay, ye please me.
O my dear credit, my dear credit.

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: sure
his minde is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: the good gods cure it.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: my honour got thorow fire, thorow stubborn, breaches
thorow battels that have been as hard to win as heaven,
thorow death himself, in all his horrid trims,
is gone for ever, ever, ever, gentlemen,
and now I am left to scornful tales and laughters,
to hootings at, pointing with fingers, that's he,
that's the brave gentleman forsook the battel,
the most wise Penyus, the disputing coward.
O my good sword, break from my side, and kill mee;
cut out the coward from my heart.

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: ye are none.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: he lyes that says so: by----he lyes, lyes basely,
baser then I have done. Come, souldiers, seek me,
I have robb'd ye of your vertues:justice, seek me,
I have broke my fair obedience, lost:shame take me,
take me, and swallow me, make ballads of me;
shame, endlesse shame:and pray do you forsake me.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: good gentlemen forsake me:
you were not wont to be commanded. Friends, pray do it,
and do not fear; for as I am a coward
I will not hurt my self:when that minde takes me,
I'll call to you, and ask your help. I dare not.Enter Petillius.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: good morrow, gentlemen; where's the tribune?

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: there.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: whence come ye, good Petillius?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: from the general.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: with what, for heavens sake?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: with good counsel, Drusus,
and love, to comfort him.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: good Regulus
step to the souldier, and allay his anger;
for he is wilde as winter.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: o, are ye there? Have at ye. Sure he's dead,
it cannot be he dare out live this fortune:
he must die, 'tis most necessary; men expect it;
and thought of life in him, goes beyond coward.
Forsake the field so basely?fie upon't:
so poorly to betray his worth? So coldly
to cut all credit from the souldier? Sure
if this man mean to live, as I should think it
beyond belief, he must retire where never
the name of Rome, the voice of arms, or honour
was known or heard of yet:he's certain dead,
or strongly means it; he's no souldier else,
no Romane in him; all he has done, but outside,
fought either drunk or desperate. Now he rises.
How does lord Penyus?

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: as ye see.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I am glad on't;
continue so still. The lord general,
the valiant general, great Swetonius-

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: no more of me is spoken; my name's perish'd.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: he that commanded fortune and the day
by his own valour and discretion,
when, as some say, Penyus refused to come,
but I believe 'em not, sent me to see ye.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: ye are welcom; and pray see me; see me well,
ye shall not see me long.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I hope so, Penyus;
the gods defend, sir.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: see me, and understand me:this is he
left to fill up your triumph; he that basely
whistled his honour off to th'winde; that coldly
shrunk in his politick head, when Rome like reapers
sweat blood, and spirit, for a glorious harvest,
and bound it up, and brought it off:that fool,
that having gold and copper offer'd him,
refus'd the wealth, and took the waste: that souldier
that being courted by loud fame and fortune,
labour in one hand, that propounds us gods,
and in the other, glory that creats us,
yet durst doubt, and be damned.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: it was an errour.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: a foul one, and a black one.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: yet the blackest
may be washt white again.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: never.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: your leave, sir,
and I beseech ye note me:for I love ye,
and bring along all comfort:are we gods,
alli'd to no infirmities? Are our natures
more then mens natures?when we slip a little
out of the way of vertue, are we lost?
Is there no medicine called sweet mercie?

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: none, Petillius;
there is no mercie in mankinde can reach me,
nor is it fit it should; I have sinn'd beyond it.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: forgivenesse meets with all faults,

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: 'tis all faults,
all sins I can commit, to be forgiven:
'tis losse of whole man in me, my discretion
to be so stupid, to arrive at pardon.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: o but the general-

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: he's a brave gentleman,
a valiant, and a loving; and I dare say
he would, as far as honour durst direct him,
make even with my fault: but 'tis not honest,
nor in his power: examples that may nourish
neglect and disobedience in whole bodies,
and totter the estates and faiths of armies,
must not be plaid withal; nor out of pitie
make a general forget his duty:
nor dare I hope more from him then is worthy.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: what would ye do?

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: die.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: so would sullen children,
women that want their wils, slaves, disobedient,
that fear the law, die. Fie, great captain; you
a man to rule men, to have thousand lives
under your regiment, and let your passion
betray your reason? I bring you all forgivenesse,
the noblest kinde commends, your place, your honour.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: prethee no more; 'tis foolish:didst not thou?
By---thou didst, I over-heard thee, there,
there where thou standst now, deliver me for rascal,
poor, dead, cold coward, miserable, wretched,
if I out-liv'd this ruine?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: i?

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: and thou didst it nobly.
Like a true man, a souldier:and I thank thee,
I thanke thee, good Petillius; thus I thank thee.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: since ye are so justly made up, let me tell ye
'tis fit ye die indeed.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: o how thou lovest me

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: for say he had forgiven ye; say the peoples whispers
were tame again, the time run out for wonder,
what must your own command think, from whose
swords
ye have taken off the edges, from whose valours
the due and recompence of arms; nay, made it doubtful
whether they knew obedience?must not these kill ye?
Say they are won to pardon ye, by meer miracle
brought to forgive ye; what old valiant souldier,
what man that loves to fight, and fight for Rome,
will ever follow you more?dare ye know these ventures?
If so, I bring ye comfort; dare ye take it?

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: no, no, Petillius, no.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: if your minde serve ye,
ye may live still; but how? Yet pardon me,
you may outwear all too; but when? And certain
there is a mercy for each fault, if tamely
a man will take't upon conditions.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: no, by no means:I am onely thinking now, sir,
(for I am resolved to go)of a most base death,
fitting the basenesse of my fault. I'll hang,

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: ye shall not; y'are a gentleman I honour,
I would else flatter ye, and force ye live,
which is far baser. Hanging? 'Tis a dogs death,
an end for slaves.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: the fitter for my basenesse.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: besides, the man that's hang'd, preaches his end,
and sits a signe for all the world to gape at.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: that's true:I'll take a fitter poison.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: no,
'tis equal ill; the death of rats, and women,
lovers, and lazie boys, that fear correction.
Die like a man.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: why my sword then.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: i, if your sword be sharp, sir,
there's nothing under heaven that's like your sword;
your sword's a death indeed.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: it shall be sharp, sir.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: why mithridates was an arrant asse
to die by poison, if all bosphorus
could lend him swords:your sword must do the deed:
'tis shame to die choak'd, fame to die and bleed.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: thou hast confirmed me:and, my good Petillius,
tell me no more I may live.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: 't was my commission;
but now I see ye in a nobler way,
a way to make all even.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: fare-well, captain:
be a good man, and fight well:be obedient:
command thy self, and then thy men. Why shakest thou?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I do not, sir.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: I would thou hadst, Petillius:
I would finde something to forsake the world with
worthy the man that dies:a kinde of earth-quake
thorow all stern valours but mine own.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I feel now
a kinde of trembling in me.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: keep it still,
as thou lov'st vertue, keep it.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: and brave captain,
the great and honoured Penyus.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: that again:
o how it heightens me again, Petillius.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: most excellent commander.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: those were mine,
mine, onely mine.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: they are still.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.l: then to keep 'em
for ever falling more, have at ye, heavens,
ye everlasting powers, I am yours: the work's done,
that neither fire, nor melting envie
shall ever conquer. Carry my last words
to the great general:kisse his hands, and say,
my soul I give to heaven, my fault to justice
which I have done upon my self:my vertue,
if ever there was any in poor Penyus,
made more, and happier, light on him. I faint.
And where there is a foe, I wish him fortune.
I die:lie lightly on my ashes, gentle earth.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: and on my sin. Fare-well, great Penyus, noise within
the souldier is in fury. Now I am glad
'tis done before he comes. This way, for me,
the way of toil; for thee, the way of honour. exit. Enter Drusus and Regulus, with souldiers.

sp.speaker: sould
sp.l: kill him, kill him, kill him.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: what will ye do?

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: good souldiers, honest souldiers.

sp.speaker: sould
sp.l: kill him, kill him, kill him.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: kill us first; we command too.

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: valiant souldiers,
consider but whose life ye seek. O Drusus,
bid him be gone, he dies else. Shall Rome say
(ye most approved souldiers) her dear children
devoured the fathers of the fights? Shall rage
and stubborn fury guide those swords to slaughter,
to slaughter of their own, to civil ruine?

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: o let 'em in: all's done, all's ended, Regulus,
Penyus has found his last eclipse. Come, souldiers,
come, and behold your miseries:come bravely,
full of your mutinious and bloody angers,
and here bestow your darts. O onely Romane,
o father of the wars.

sp.speaker: Reg
sp.l: why stand ye stupid?
Where be your killing furies? Whose sword now
shall first be sheath'd in Penyus? Do ye weep?
Howl out, ye wretches, ye have cause:howl ever.
Who shall now lead ye fortunate? Whose valour
preserve ye to the glory of your countrey?
Who shall march out before ye, coy'd and courted
by all the mistrisses of war, care, counsel,
quick-ey'd experience, and victory twin'd to him?
Who shall beget ye deeds beyond inheritance
to speak your names, and keep your honours living,
when children fail, and time that takes all with him,
build houses for ye to oblivion?

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: o ye poor desperate fools:no more now, souldiers;
go home, and hang your arms up; let rust rot 'em;
and humble your stern valours to soft prayers;
for ye have sunk the frame of all your vertues;
the sun that warm'd your bloods is set for ever:
I'll kisse thy honour'd cheek. Fare well, great Penyus,
thou thunder-bolt, fare-well. Take up the body:
to morrow morning to the camp convey it.
There to receive due ceremonies. That eye
that blindes himself with weeping, gets most glory.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Swetonius, Junius, Decius, Demetrius, Curius, and souldiers: Bonduca, two daughters, and Nennius, above. Drum and colours.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: bring up the catapults and shake the wall,
we will not be out-brav'd thus.

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: shake the earth,
ye cannot shake our souls. Bring up your rams,
and with their armed heads, make the fort totter,
ye do but rock us into death. exit Nennius.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: see sir,
see the icenian queen in all her glory
from the strong battlements proudly appearing,
as if she meant to give us lashes.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: yeeld, queen.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: I am unacquainted with that language, Roman.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: yeeld, honour'd lady, and expect our mercie, exit Decius
we love thy noblenesse.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: I thank ye, ye say well;
but mercie and love are sins in Rome and hell.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: ye cannot scape our strength; ye must yeeld, ladie,
ye must adore and fear the power of Rome.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: if Rome be earthly, why should any knee
with bending adoration worship her?
She's vitious; and your partiall selves confesse,
aspires the height of all impietie:
therefore 'tis fitter I should reverence
the thatched houses where the Britains dwell
in carelesse mirth, where the blest houshold gods
see nought but chaste and simple puritie.
'Tis not high power that makes a place divine,
nor that the men from gods derive their line.
But sacred thoughts in holy bosoms stor'd,
make people noble, and the place ador'd.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: beat the wall deeper.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: beat it to the center,
we will not sink one thought.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: I'll make ye.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: no.

sp.speaker: 2. Dau
sp.l: o mother, these are fearfull hours:speak gentlyEnter Petillius
to these fierce men, they will afford ye pitie.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: pitie? Thou fearful girl; 'tis for those wretches
that miserie makes tame. Wouldst thou live lesse?
Wast not thou born a princesse? Can my blood,
and thy brave fathers spirit, suffer in thee
so base a separation from thy self,
as mercie from these tyrants? Thou lov'st lust sure,
and long'st to prostitute thy youth and beautie
to common slaves for bread. Say they had mercie;
the divel a relenting conscience:
the lives of kings rest in their diadems,
which to their bodies lively souls do give,
and ceasing to be kings, they cease to live.
Show such another fear, and-----
I'll fling thee to their furie.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: he is dead then?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I think so certainly; yet all my means, sir,
even to the hazzard of my life---

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: no more:
wee must not seem to mourn here.Enter Decius.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: there's a breach made,
is it your will we charge, sir?

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: once more mercie,
mercie to all that yeeld.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: I scorn to answer:
speak to him girle; and hear thy sister.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh
sp.l: generall,
hear me, and mark me well, and look upon me
directly in my face, my womans face,
whose onely beautie is the hate it bears ye;
see with thy narrowest eyes, thy sharpest wishes,
into my soul, and see what there inhabits;
see if one fear, one shadow of a terrour,
one palenesse dare appear but from my anger,
to lay hold on your mercies. No, ye fools,
poor fortunes fools, we were not born for triumphs,
to follow your gay sports, and fill your slaves
with hoots and acclamations.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: brave behaviour.

sp.speaker: 1 daugh
sp.l: the children of as great as Rome, as noble,
our names before her, and our deeds her envie;
must we gild ore your conquest, make your state,
that is not fairly strong, but fortunate?
No, no, ye Romanes, we have ways to scape ye,
to make yee poor again, indeed our prisoners,
and stick our triumphs full.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: 's death, I shall love her.

sp.speaker: 1 daugh
sp.l: to torture ye with suffering, like our slaves;
to make ye curse our patience, wish the world
were lost again, to win us onely, and esteem
the end of all ambitions.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: do ye wonder?
We'll make our monuments in spite of fortune,
in spight of all your eagles wings:we'll work
a pitch above ye; and from our height we'll stoop
as fearlesse of your bloody fears; and fortunate,
as if we prey'd on heartlesse doves.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: strange stiffnesse.
Decius, go charge the breach. exit Decius.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: charge it home, Romane,
we shall deceive thee else. Where's Nennius?Enter Nennius.

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: they have made a mighty breach.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: stick in thy body,
and make it good but half an hour.

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: I'll do it.

sp.speaker: 1 daugh
sp.l: and then be sure to die.

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: it shall go hard else.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: fare well with all my heart; we shall meet yonder,
where few of these must come.

sp.speaker: Nen
sp.l: gods take thee, lady. exit Nennius.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: bring up the swords, and poison.Enter one with swords, and a great cup.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh
sp.l: o my fortune

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: how, how, ye whore?

sp.speaker: 2 daugh
sp.l: good mother, nothing to offend ye.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: here, wench:
behold us, Romanes.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: mercy yet.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: no talking:
puff; there goes all your pitie. Come, short prayers,
and let's dispatch the businesse:you begin,
shrink not; I'll see ye do't.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh
sp.l: o gentle mother,
o Romanes, o my heart; I dare not.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: woman, woman,
unnatural woman.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh
sp.l: o perswade her, Romanes:
alas, I am young, and would live. Noble mother,
can ye kill that ye gave life? Are my yeers
fit for destruction?

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: yeeld, and be a queen still,
a mother, and a friend.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: ye talk:come, hold it,
and put it home.

sp.speaker: 1 daugh
sp.l: fie, sister, fie,
what would you live to be?

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: a whore still.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh
sp.l: mercie.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: hear her, thou wretched woman.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh
sp.l: mercie, mother:
o whither will you send me? I was once
your darling, your delight.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: o gods,
fear in my family? Do it, and nobly.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh
sp.l: o do not frown then.

sp.speaker: 1 daugh
sp.l: do it, worthy sister:
'tis nothing, 'tis a pleasure; we'll go with ye.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh
sp.l: o if I knew but whither.

sp.speaker: 1 daugh
sp.l: to the blessed,
where we shall meet our father.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: woman.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: talk not.

sp.speaker: 1 daugh
sp.l: where nothing but true joy is.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: that's a good wench, mine own sweet girl; put
it close to thee.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh
sp.l: o comfort me still, for heavens sake.

sp.speaker: 1 daugh
sp.l: where eternal
our youths are, and our beauties; where no wars come,
nor lustful slaves to ravish us.

sp.speaker: 2 daugh
sp.l: that steels me:
a long farewel to this world.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: good:I'll help thee.

sp.speaker: 1 daugh
sp.l: the next is mine.
Shew me a Romane lady in all your stories,
dare do this for her honour:they are cowards,
eat coals like compell'd cats: your great saint lucrece
di'd not for honour; tarquin topt her well,
and mad she could not hold him, bled.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: by---
I am in love:I would give an hundred pound now
but to lie with this womans behaviour. O the devil.

sp.speaker: 1 daugh
sp.l: ye shall see me example. All your Rome,
if I were proud, and lov'd ambition;
if I were lustful, all your ways of pleasure;
if I were greedie, all the wealth ye conquer--

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: make haste.

sp.speaker: 1 daugh
sp.l: I will. Could not intice to live
but two short hours this frailty: would ye learn
how to die bravely, Romanes, to fling off
this case of flesh, lose all your cares for ever?
Live as we have done, well, and fear the gods,
hunt honour, and not nations with your swords,
keep your mindes humble, your devotions high;
so shall ye learn the noblest part, to die.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: I come, wench; to ye all fates hang-men; you
that ease the aged destinies, and cut
the threds of kingdoms, as they draw 'em; here,
here's a draught would ask no lesse then Caesar
to pledge it for the glories sake.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: great lady.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: make up your own conditions.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: so we will.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: stay.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: stay.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: be any thing.

sp.speaker: Bond
sp.l: a saint, Swetonius,
when thou shalt fear, and die like a slave. Ye fools,
ye should have ti'd up death first, when ye conquer'd,
ye sweat for us in vain else: see him here,
he's ours still, and our friend; laughs at your pities;
and we command him with as easie reins
as do our enemies. I feel the poison.
Poor vanquish'd Romanes, with what matchlesse tortures
could I now rack ye? But I pitie ye,
desiring to die quiet: nay, so much
I hate to prosecute my victory,
that I will give ye counsel ere I die.
If you will keep your laws and empire whole,
place in your Romane flesh a Britain soul.Enter Decius.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: desperate and strange.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: 'tis won, sir, and the Britains
all put to th'sword.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: give her fair funeral;
she was truely noble, and a queen.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: -----take it,
a love-mange grown upon me? What, a spirit?

sp.speaker: iun
sp.l: I am glad of this, I have found ye.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: in my belly,
o how it tumbles?

sp.speaker: iun
sp.l: ye good gods, I thank ye.Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Quintus. Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Caratach upon a rock, and Hengo by him, sleeping.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: thus we afflicted Britains climb for safeties,
and to avoid our dangers, seek destructions,
thus we awake to sorrows. O thou woman,
thou agent for adversities, what curses
this day belong to thy improvidence?
To britanie by thy means, what sad millions
of widows weeping eyes? The strong mans valour
thou hast betraid to fury; the childes fortune
to fear, and want of friends:whose pieties
might wipe his mournings off, and build his sorrows
a house of rest by his blest ancestors:
the virgins thou hast rob'd of all their wishes,
blasted their blowing hopes, turn'd their songs,
their mirthful marriage-songs to funerals,
the land thou hast left a wildernesse of wretches.
The boy begins to stir:thy safety made,
would my soul were in heaven.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: o noble uncle,
look out; I dream'd we were betraid. a soft dead march within.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: no harm, boy;
'tis but thy emptinesse that breeds these fancies;
thou shalt have meat anon.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: a little, uncle,
and I shall hold out bravely. What are those?
Look, uncle, look, those multitudes that march there?
They come upon us stealing by.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: I see 'em;
and prethee be not fearful.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: now ye hate me,
would I were dead.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: thou know'st I love thee dearly.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: did I ere shrink yet, uncle? Were I a man now,
I should be angry with ye.Enter Drusus, Regulus, and souldiers, with Penyus herse, drums and colours.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: my sweet chicken,
see, thy have reach'd us, as it seems they bear
some souldiers body, by their solemn gestures,
and sad solemnities; it well appears too
to be of eminence. Most worthy souldiers,
let me intreat your knowledge to inform me
what noble body that is which you bear
with such a sad and ceremonious grief,
as if ye meant to woo the world and nature
to be in love with death? Most honourable
excellent Romanes, by your ancient valours,
as ye love fame, resolve me.

sp.speaker: sould
sp.l: 'tis the body
of the great captain Penyus, by himself
made cold and spiritlesse.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: o stay, ye Romanes,
by the religion which you owe those gods
that lead ye on to victories, by those glories
which made even pride a vertue in ye.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: stay:
what's thy will, Caratach?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: set down the body,
the body of the noblest of all Romanes,
as ye expect an offering at your graves
from your friends sorrows, set it down a while,
that with your griefs an enemy may mingle:
a noble enemy that loves a souldier;
and lend a tear to vertue:even your foes,
your wild foes, as you call'd us, are yet stor'd
with fair affections, our hearts fresh, our spirits,
though sometimes stubborn, yet when vertue dies,
soft and relenting as a virgins prayers.
O set it down.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: set down the body, souldiers.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: thou hallowed relique, thou rich diamond
cut with thine own dust; thou for whose wide fame
the world appears too narrow, mans all thoughts,
had they all tongues, too silent; thus I bow
to thy most honour'd ashes; though an enemy,
yet friend to all thy worths: sleep peaceably;
happinesse crown thy soul, and in thy earth
some lawrel fix his seat, there grow, and flourish,
and make thy grave an everlasting triumph.
Fare well all glorious wars, now thou art gone,
and honest arms adieu:all noble battels
maintain'd in thirst of honour, not of blood,
fare well for ever.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: was this Romane, uncle,
so good a man?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: thou never knew'st thy father.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: he di'd before I was born.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: this worthy Romane
was such another piece of endlesse honour,
such a brave soul dwelt in him:their proportions
and faces were not much unlike, boy:excellent natures,
see how it works into his eyes, mine own boy.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: the multitudes of these men, and their fortunes,
could never make me fear yet:one mans goodnesse-

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: o now thou pleasest me: weep still, my childe,
as if thou saw'st me dead; with such a flux
or flood of sorrow:still thou pleasest me.
And worthy souldiers, pray receive these pledges,
these hatchments of our griefs, and grace us so much
to place 'em on his hearse. Now if ye please,
bear off the noble burden; raise his pile
high as olympus, making heaven to wonder
to see a star upon earth outshining theirs.
And ever loved, ever living be
thy honoured and most sacred memory.

sp.speaker: Dru
sp.l: thou hast done honestly, good Caratach,
and when thou diest, a thousand vertuous Romanes
shall sing thy soul to heaven. Now march on, souldiers.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: now dry thine eyes, my boy.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: are they all gone?
I could have wept this hour yet.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: come, take cheer,
and raise thy spirit, childe:if but this day
thou canst bear out thy faintnesse, the night coming
I'll fashion our escape.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: pray fear not me;
indeed I am very heartie.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: be so still;
his mischiefs lessen, that controls his ill.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: what do I ail, i'th'name of heaven? I did but see her,
and see her die: she stinks by this time strongly,
abominably stinks:she was a woman,
a thing I never car'd for:but to die so,
so confidently, bravely, strongly; o the devil,
I have the bots, by--; she scorn'd us, strangely,
all we could do, or durst do; threatned us
with such a noble anger, and so governed
with such a fiery spirit---; the plain bots;
a---upon the bots, the love-bots:hang me,
hang me even out o'th'way, directly hang me.
O pennie pipers, and most painful penners
of bountiful new ballads, what a subject,
what a sweet subject for your silver sounds,
is crept upon ye?Enter Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: here he is; have at him. sings
she set the sword unto her brest,
great pitie it was to see,
that three drops of her life-warm blood,
run trickling down her knee.
Art thou there, bonny boy? And ifaith how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: well, gramercie, how dost thou? H'as found me,
sented me out:the shame the devil ow'd me,
h'as kept his day with. And what news, Junius?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: it was an old tale ten thousand times told,
of a young lady was turn'd into mold,
her life was lovely, her death it was bold.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: a cruel rogue; now h'as drawn pursue on me,
he hunts me like a devil. No more singing;
thou hast got a cold:come, let's go drink some sack, boy.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: why dost thou laugh?
What mares nest hast thou found?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: ha, ha, ha.
I cannot laugh alone:Decius, Demetrius,
Curius: o my sides. Ha, ha, ha, ha,
the strangest jest.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: prethee no more.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: the admirablest fooling.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: thou art the prettiest fellow.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: sirs.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: why Junius,
prethee away, sweet Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: let me sing then.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: whoa, here's a stir now:sing a song o'six pence,
by-----(if)prethee; -----on't:Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: I must either sing, or laugh.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: and what's your reason?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: what's that to you?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: and I must whistle.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: do so.
O, I hear 'em coming.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I have a little businesse.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: thou shalt not go, believe it:what a gentleman
of thy sweet conversation?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: captain Junius,
sweet captain, let me go with all celerity;
things are not always one:and do not question,
nor jeer, nor gybe:none of your doleful ditties,
nor your sweet conversation:you will finde then
I may be anger'd.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: by no means, Petillius;
anger a man that never knew passion?
'Tis most impossible:a noble captain,
a wise and generous gentleman?

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: tom puppie,
leave this way to abuse me:I have found ye,
but for your mothers sake I will forgive ye.
Your subtil understanding may discover
(as you think) some trim toy to make you merry;
some straw to tickle ye; but do not trust to't;
y'are a young man, and may do well; be sober;
carry your self discreetly.Enter Decius, Demetrius, Curius.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: how does the brave Petillius?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: monstrous merry:
we two were talking what a kinde of thing
I was when I was in love; what a strange monster
for little boys and girls to wonder at;
how like a fool I lookt.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: so they do all,
like great dull slavering fools.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: Petillius saw too.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: no more of this; 'tis scurvie; peace.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: how nastily,
indeed how beastly all I did became me?
How I forgot to blow my nose? There he stands,
an honest and a wise man; if himself
(I dare avouch it boldly, for I know it)
should finde himself in love-

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I am angry.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: surely his wise self would hang his beastly self,
his understanding self so mawl his asse-self--

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: he's bound to do it; for he knows the follies,
the poverties, and basenesse that belongs to't,
h'as read upon the reformations long.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: he has so,

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: 'tis true, and he must do't:
nor is it fit indeed any such coward -

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: you'll leave prating.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: should dare come neer the regiments, specially
those curious puppies (for believe there are such)
that onely love behaviours:those are dog-whelps,
dwindle away, because a woman dies well;
commit with passions onely:fornicate
with the free spirit meerly:you, Petillius,
for you have long observ'd the world.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: dost thou hear?
I'll beat thee damnably within these three hours:
go pray; may be I'll kill thee. Farewel Jack Daws. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: what a strange thing he's grown?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: I am glad he is so:
and stranger he shall be, before I leave him.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: is't possible her meer death-----

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: I observ'd him,
and found him taken, infinitely taken
with her bravery:I have follow'd him,
and seen him kisse his sword since, court his scabbard,
call dying, dainty deer; her brave minde, mistris;
casting a thousand ways, to give those forms,
that he might lie with 'em, and get old armors:
he had got me o'th'hip once:if shall go hard, friends,
but he shall find his own coin.Enter Macer.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: how now Macer?Enter Judas
is Judas yet come in?

sp.speaker: mac
sp.l: yes, and has lost
most of his men too. Here he is.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: what news?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: I have lodg'd him; rouze him he that dares.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: where, Judas?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: on a steep rock, i'th'woods, the boy too with him,
and there he swears he will keep his christmas, gentlemen,
but he will come away with full conditions,
bravely, and like a Britain: he paid part of us,
yet I think we fought bravely:for mine own part,
I was four several times at half sword with him,
twice stood his partizan:but the plain truth is,
he's a meer devil, and no man:i'th'end he swing'd us,
and swing'd us soundly too:he fights by with-craft:
yet for all hat I see him lodg'd,

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: take more men,
and scout him round. Macer, march you along.
What victuals has he?

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: not a piece of bisket,
not so much as will stop a tooth; nor water,
more then they make themselves:they lie
just like a brace of bear-whelps, close, and crafty,
sucking their fingers for their food.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: cut off then
all hope of that way:take sufficient forces.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: but use no foul play, on your lives:that man
that does him mischief by deceit, I'll kill him.

sp.speaker: Macer
sp.l: he shall have fair play, he deserves it.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: heark ye,
what should I do there then? You are brave captains,
most valiant men; go up your selves; use vertue,
see what will come on't:pray the gentleman
to come down, and be taken. Ye all know him,
I think ye have felt him too:there ye shall find him,
his sword by his side, plums of a pound weight by him
will make your chops ake:you'll finde it a more labour
to win him living, then climbing of a crowes nest.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: away, and compasse him; we shall come up
I am sure within these two hours. Watch him close.

sp.speaker: Macer
sp.l: he shall flee thorow the air, if he escape us. a sad noise within.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: what's this loud lamentation?

sp.speaker: mac
sp.l: the dead body
of the great Penyus is new come to th'camp sir.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.l: dead

sp.speaker: Macer
sp.l: by himself, they say.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: I fear'd that fortune.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: peace guide him up to heaven.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: away good Macer. Exeunt.Macer and Judas. Enter Swetonius, Drusus, Regulus, Petillius.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: if thou be'st guilty,
some sullen plague thou hat'st most light upon thee:
the regiment return on Junius,
hee well deserves it.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: so.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: draw out three companies,
yours Decius, Junius, and thou Petillius,
and make up instantly to Caratach,
he's in the wood before ye; we shall follow
after due ceremony done to the dead,
the noble dead:come, let's go burn the body.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: the regiment given from me; disgrac'd openly;
in love too with a trifle to abuse me?
A merry world, a fine world: serv'd seven yeers
to be an asse o'both sides, sweet Petillius,
you have brought your hogs to a fine market:you are wise, sir
your honourable brain-pan full of crotchets,
an understanding gentleman; your projects
cast with assurance ever: wouldst not thou now
be bang'd about the pate, Petillius?
Answer to that sweet souldier; surely, surely,
I think ye would; pull'd by the nose, kick'd; hang thee,
thou art the arrant'st rascall:trust thy wisdome
with any thing of weight; the winde with feathers.
Out ye blind puppie; you command? You govern?
Dig for a groat a day, or serve a swine-herd;
too noble for thy nature too. I must up;
but what I shall do there, let time discover. exit

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Macer and Judas, with meat and a bottle.

sp.speaker: mac
sp.l: hang it o'th'side o'th'rock, as though the Britains
stole hither to relieve him; who first ventures
to fetch it off, is ours. I cannot see him.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: he lies close in a hole above, I know it,
gnawing upon his anger: ha? No, 'tis not he,

sp.speaker: Macer
sp.l: 'tis but the shaking of the boughs.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: ---shake 'em,
I am sure they shake me soundly. There.

sp.speaker: Macer
sp.l: 'tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: make no noise: if he stir, a deadly tempest
of huge stones fall upon us:'tis done:away close. exit Enter Caratach.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: sleep stil, sleep sweetly child, 'tis all thou feedst on.
No gentle Britain neer; no valiant charitie
to bring thee food?poor knave, thou art sick, extreme sick,
almost grown wild for meat; and yet thy goodnesse
will not confesse, nor show it. All the woods
are double lin'd with souldiers; no way left us
to make a noble scape:I'll sit down by thee,
and when thou wak'st, either get meat to save thee,
or lose my life i'th' purchase. Good gods comfort thee.Enter Junius, Decius, Petillius, guide.

sp.speaker: guide
sp.l: ye are not far off now, sir.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: draw the companies
the closest way thorow the woods; we'll keep on this way.

sp.speaker: guide
sp.l: I will sir:half a furlong more you'll come
within the sight o'th'rock; keep on the left side,
you'll be discoverd else:I'll lodge your companies
in the wilde vines beyond ye.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: do ye mark him?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: yes, and am sorry for him.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: Junius,
pray let me speak two words with you.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: walk afore,
I'll overtake ye straight.

sp.speaker: Dec
sp.l: I will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: now, captain.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: you have oft told me you have lov'd me, Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: most sure I told you truth then.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: and that love
should not deny me any honest thing.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: it shall not.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: dare ye swear it?
I have forgot all passages between us
that have been ill, forgiven too, forgot you.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: what would this man have? By---I do, sir,
so it be fit to grant ye.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: 'tis most honest.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: why, then I'll do it.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: kill mee.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: how?

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: pray kill me.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: kill ye?

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: i, kill me quickly, suddenly,
now kill me.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: on what reason? Ye amaze me.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: if ye do love me, kill me, ask me not why:
I would be kill'd, and by you.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: mercy on me,
what ails this man? Petillius.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: pray ye dispatch me,
ye are not safe whilest I live:I am dangerous,
troubled extremely, even to mischief, Junius,
an enemie to all good men: fear not, 'tis justice;
I shall kill you else.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: tell me but the cause,
and I will do it.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I am disgrac'd, my service
slighted, and unrewarded by the generall,
my hopes left wilde and naked; besides these,
I am grown ridiculous, an asse, a folly
I dare not trust my self with:prethee kill me.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: all these may be redeem'd as easily
as you would heal your finger.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: nay--

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: stay, I'll do it,
you shall not need your anger:but first, Petillius,
you shall unarm your self; I dare not trust
a man so bent to mischief.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: there's my sword;
and do it handsomely.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: yes, I will kill ye,
beleeve that certaine:but first I'll lay before ye
the most extreme fool ye have plaid in this,
the honour purpos'd for ye, the great honour
the generall intended ye,

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: how?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: and then I'll kill ye,
because ye shall die miserable. Know sir,
the regiment was given me, but till time
call'd ye to do some worthie deed might stop
the peoples ill thoughts of ye for lord Penyus,
I mean his death. How soon this time's come to ye,
and hasted by Swetonius? Go, sayes he,
Junius and Decius, and go thou Petillius;
distinctly, thou Petillius, and draw up,
to take stout Caratach:there's the deed purpos'd,
a deed to take off all faults, of all natures:
and thou Petillius; mark it, there's the honour,
and that done, all made even.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: stay.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: no, I'll kill ye.
He knew thee absolute, and full in souldier,
daring beyond all dangers, found thee out
according to the boldnesse of thy spirit,
a subject, such a subject.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: heark ye Junius,
I will live now.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: by no means. Wooed thy worth,
held thee by the chin up, as thou sankst, and shew'd thee
how honour held her arms out:come, make ready,
since ye will die an asse.

sp.speaker: petil
sp.l: thou wilt not kill me.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: by-----but I will sir:I'll have no man dangerous
live to destroy me afterward. Besides, you have gotten
honour enough, let young men rise now. Nay,
I do preceive too by the generall, (which
is one main cause ye shall die) how ere he carry it,
such a strong doting on ye, that I fear,
you shall command in chief:how are we paid then?
Come, if you will pray, dispatch it.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: is there no way?

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: not any way to live.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: I will do any thing,
redeem my self at any price:good Junius,
let me but die upon the rock, but offer
my life up like a souldier.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: you will seek then
to out-doe every man.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: beleeve it Junius,
you shall goe stroak by stroak with me,

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: you'll leave off too,
as you are noble, and a souldier,
for ever these mad fancies.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: dare ye trust me?
By all that's good and honest.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: there's your sword then,
and now come on a new man: vertue guide thee. Exeunt. Enter Caratach and Hengo on the rock.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: courage my boy, I have found meat:look Hengo,
look where some blessed Britain, to preserve thee,
has hung a little food and drink:cheer up boy,
do not forsake me now.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: o uncle, uncle,
I feel I cannot stay long:yet I'll fetch it,
to keep your noble life: uncle, I am heart whole,
and would live.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: thou shalt, long I hope.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: but my head, uncle:
me thinks the rock goes round. Enter Macer and jud.

sp.speaker: Macer
sp.l: mark 'em well, Judas.

sp.speaker: Jud
sp.l: peace, as you love your life.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: do not you hear
the noise of bels?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: of bels boy? 'Tis thy fancie,
alas, thy bodie's full of wind.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: me thinks sir,
they ring a strange sad knell, a preparation
to some neer funerall of state:nay, weep not,
mine owne sweet uncle, you will kill me sooner.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: o my poor chicken.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: fie, faint-hearted uncle:
come, tie me in your belt, and let me down.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: I'll go my self, boy.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: no, as ye love mee, uncle;
I will not eat it, if I doe not fetch it;
the danger onely I desire:pray tie me.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: I will, and all my care hang ore thee:come child,
my valiant child.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: let me down apace, uncle,
and ye shall see how like a daw I'll whip it
from all their policies:for 'tis most certain
a Roman train:and ye must hold me sure too,
you'll spoil all else. When I have brought it uncle,
wee'll be as merry--

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: go i'th'name of heaven boy.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: quick, quick, uncle, I have it. Oh. Judas shoots Hengo.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: what ailest thou?

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: o my best uncle, I am slain.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: I see yee, and heaven direct my hand:destruction Caratach kils Judas with a stone from the rock
go with thy coward soul. How dost thou boy?
Oh villain, pocky villain.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: o uncle, uncle,
oh how it pricks mee:am I preserv'd for this?
Extremely pricks me.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: coward, rascall coward,
dogs eat thy flesh.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: oh I bleed hard:I faint too, out upon't,
how sick I am? The lean rogue, uncle.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: look boy,
I have laid him sure enough.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: have ye knockt his brains out?

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: I warrant thee for stirring more:cheer up, child.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: hold my sides hard, stop, stop, oh wretched fortune,
must we part thus? Still I grow sicker, uncle.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: heaven look upon this noble child.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: I once hop'd
I should have liv'd to have met these bloody Romans
at my swords point, to have reveng'd my father,
to have beaten 'em: oh hold me hard. But uncle--

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: thou shalt live still I hope boy. Shall I draw it?

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: ye draw away my soul then. I would live
a little longer; spare me heavens, but onely
to thank you for your tender love. Good uncle,
good noble uncle weep not.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: oh my chicken,
my deer boy, what shall I lose?

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: why, a child,
that must have died how-ever; had this scap'd me,
feaver or famine:I was born to die, sir.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: but thus unblown, my boy?

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: I goe the straighter
my journey to the gods: sure I shall know ye
when ye come, uncle.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: yes, boy.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: and I hope
wee shall enjoy together that great blessednesse
you told me of.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: most certain, child.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: I grow cold,
mine eyes are going.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: lift 'em up.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: pray for me;
and noble uncle, when my bones are ashes,
think of your little nephew. Mercie.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: mercie.
You blessed angels take him.

sp.speaker: Heng
sp.l: kisse me:so.
Farewell, farewell. dies.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: farewell the hopes of Britain,
thou royall graft, farewell for ever. Time and death,
ye have done your worst. Fortune now see, now proudly
pluck off thy vail, and view thy triumph:look,
look what thou hast brought this land to. Oh fair flower,
how lovely yet thy ruines show, how sweetly
even death embraces thee the peace of heaven,
the fellowship of all great souls be with thee.Enter Petillius and Junius on the rock
hah? Dare ye Romans? Ye shall win me bravely.
Thou art mine. fight.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: not yet, sir.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: breathe ye, ye poor Romans,
and come up all, with all your ancient valours,
like a rough winde I'll shake your souls, and send 'em--Enter Swetonius, and all the Roman captains.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: yeeld thee bold Caratach; by all-----
as I am souldier, as I envie thee,
I'll use thee like thy self, the valiant Britain.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: brave soldier yeeld; thou stock of arms and honor,
thou filler of the world with fame and glory.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: most worthy man, we'l woo thee, be thy prisoners.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: excellent Britain, do me but that honour,
that more to me then conquests, that true happinesse,
to be my friend.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: o Romans, see what here is:
had this boy liv'd---

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: for fames sake, for thy swords sake,
as thou desirest to build thy vertues greater:
by all that's excellent in man, and honest--

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: I do beleeve: ye have had me a brave foe;
make we a noble friend, and from your goodnesse,
give this boy honourable earth to lie in.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: he shall have fitting funerall.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: I yeeld then,
not to your blowes, but your brave courtesies.

sp.speaker: Petill
sp.l: thus we conduct then to the arms of peace
the wonder of the world.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: thus I embrace thee, flourish
and let it be no flattery that I tell thee,
thou art the onely souldier.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: how to thank ye
I must hereafter finde upon your usage.
I am for Rome?

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: ye must.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: then Rome shall know
the man that makes her spring of glory grow.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: Petillius, you have shown much worth this day,
redeem'd much errour,
ye have my love again, preserve it. Junius,
with you I make him equall in the regiment.

sp.speaker: Jun
sp.l: the elder and the nobler. I'll give place, sir.

sp.speaker: Swet
sp.l: ye shew a friends soul.
March on, and through the camp in every tongue.
The vertues of great Caratach be sung. Exeunt.
